description:
This hole in the wall is one of my favorite bars now! This bar is small and cozy and it's the perfect place to come to with 1-2 friends, or even alone! The setting is dark and intimate, and it's pretty quiet in here (the TV plays softly in a corner). Note: this bar is cash only, but there is an ATM in the corner if you really need it. A restroom is available in the basement, but you need a bartenders permission to open the gate to use it. In general, the place is very clean.

I was served by a female bartender who was very friendly! I asked for recommendations for sweet drinks, and I was pleasantly surprised! After a few rounds with my friend, she offered us a couple free shots of "real" fireball from Hong Kong, and some warm sake. After she was off her shift, she was replaced by a guy named Mark, who is now the coolest bartender I know. He is an enigma, with lots of interesting stories to tell. I learned to play Liars Dice at this bar with my friend, and Mark is apparently unbeatable. I'd love to come back here again!
author: Tammy W.

description:
A must for a drink . Awesome , fun 
Staff  China town . Love this place ... been coming 
Here everything I come to san fransico !
author: Lucy M.

description:
This is a terrible bar. Do not come to this bar. 
...
...















...
...
Ok, if you read this far, come here. The usual bartender is Mark, who is crazy as shit and likely my favorite bartender ever. He is amazing, pours great drinks, and runs this place like a boss. Come in here and revel in one of the best damn bars anywhere. As others have said - cash only! And be ready for strong opinions! If there are Chinese patrons here, it's some amazing dialogue!!!!
author: Dave S.

description: Stopped in here during let San Fran visit . Small establishment with great service and environment.
author: Norma H.

description: Nice dive bar spot in Chinatown. Incredibly fun. Cash only though! I got the Chinese mai tai but my friend got the Buddha beer and loved that
author: Sharvari J.

description:
DO NOT COME HERE! it's a terrible, terrible place.

I may be trying to keep Chinatown's best kept secret just that...
author: Christopher D.

description: Small locals bar with great chi! Excellent feel and comfortable atmosphere. Remember this is a cash only business.
author: Bruce B.

description:
If you're looking for a low-key dive bar, I totally recommend coming here especially if you're in the Chinatown area. If you're looking to also get a quick beer after some bomb Chinese food, then stop in.

This place is tiny but it'll do the job on a Friday night over a couple Tsingtaos. Oh yea, it's cash only here so load up.
author: Allister D.

description:
Smaller local dive spot more or less right off the touristy part of chinatown. 

Parking is street only which means there is no parking. There is a garage over on portsmouth square, and some kind of lot down a bit off washington but like a lot of things in the city you are best served by coming here some way that does not involve driving.

This is a smaller, almost tiny bar. The seating is counter only, which is fine as it offers the best service. They've a tv which is viewable from any spot in the bar, and there are some murals to look at should you want to. No taps but the spirit wall is better then most divey spots nearby. It's cash only but there is a third party atm on premises should you so desire. The house special is of course, buddha beer. Tastes somewhat like Heineken but is a lot cheaper and has a clever buddha shaped bottle. Some folks think it's from Laos, Thailand or China but it actually seems to be brewed in Australia of all places. While all this is fine and good, the bartenders are the owners and they simply rock at what they do. Superior service is the norm here. Bonus points awarded for being ultra clean-not necessarily the most common thing in this area- and for offering the ability to drink low cost beer marketed to Asia brewed in Australia in downtown San Francisco. 

Four stars for a solid, unpresuming international bar in ye old chinatown.
author: Steven W.

description: Great local bar in Chinatown.  Limited selection of drinks, but the atmosphere makes up for it.  If you like dive bars, you have to visit this place.
author: Gene L.

description: In my first few hours ever of being in San Francisco I headed straight for Chinatown. After walking around mostly aimlessly I looked for a place to sit down and settle in and Buddha Lounge looked like the perfect spot. There were only a few other people in the bar when I walked in, along with the owners. They don't serve any draft beer so I ordered a bottle of Anchor Steam. The bartender lady promptly asked for payment and I thought that was funny and straight to the point. She was making popcorn in the microwave and afterwards handed it out in bowls to the patrons. There were a few regulars that stopped in that she seemed happy to see. They have a jukebox here but unfortunately it can't be controlled by an app and doesn't play unless someone's paying and picking it. This made for some dead air moments until one of the regulars put on a ton of songs which I appreciated. Buddha Lounge was definitely a welcome retreat from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown and made for an interesting experience that could not have been a better introduction to San Francisco.
author: Emily B.

description:
One of my favorite dive bars in SF ...if you're in the Chinatown/North Beach area check it out ...it reminds me of chinatown of old ...the owners I believe (husband and wife) run this joint quite efficiently ...the few times I've been they are good with not letting your beer/drinks run dry! Can't remember the name of the chinese liquer they have in the small round bottle but it's quite potent ..lol. 

There's a decent amount of seating and a TV that they usually have sports on...plenty of places to eat nearby...check it out!
author: Carlos G.

description: Cool little dive bar in Chinatown. It looked like it was run by a husband and wife which I thought was cool, and the drinks were good ! Not much to do inside but it's a chill place to have a drink
author: Jessica R.

description:
The first thing that I ever heard about Buddha Lounge is that they have a gate that you have to get buzzed into to go downstairs and use the restroom.  This is true.  

Buddha Lounge is a beloved little dive bar on Grant Street in Chinatown.  A lot of people have a lot of great things to say about this bar.  I get the sense that they have a good regular crowd.  I tend to drop in just while passing through Chinatown for a variety of reasons.  To me, this is a pretty textbook Chinatown Dive Bar which doesn't have any truly stand out feature but is still solid enough all around to stay relevant.  Personally, I can't get as excited as some people do - but I like it none-the-less.

Three Things:

1.  Chinese Mai Tai.  They have it here too.  You may have heard of another bar in the 'hood that offers this drink.  I tried the Buddha Lounge version and I was quite pleased.
2.  Get a Buddha Beer.  They only have bottled beer, no drafts.  No good strong beer.  A Buddha Beer makes for a good photo.
3.  The buzz in bathroom.  It exists.  But, on the bathroom note, this is also a handy last stop before catching an Uber away from Chinatown.

This is an interesting bar.  I rarely stay long when I come, but I'll keep coming back.
author: Adam S.

description:
Very divey bar,  but the vibe was great we felt like like San Franciscans as we meshed with the locals in there. Prices are cheap, they have a jukebox, and they have buddha beers which was the beer of choice at $5 a bottle. They didn't have the Three Penis wine, so I have to go back to try it. The beer tasted like heineken but it was the experience, we went for the experience. the Bartender was really cool and very informative on the bar. You have to get buzzed in through a fence to access the bathroom that was really cool. 

1 Star for ambience

1 Star for staff

1 Star for prices 

1 Star for location 

I would definitely recommend anyone visiting SF to come here.
author: Esteban I.

description: Really cool place. Totally chill on a Saturday afternoon. The bartender is Uber cool to talk to and the people who visit this place are great to hang with.
author: Alex D.

description: The Buddha Lounge is a good spot if you enjoy frequenting dive bars. While the Chinese mai tai was a hit with the group, the t-shirts were the biggest crowd pleaser. Certainly a place to stop in and grab a drink but make sure you have cash since this is a cash only establishment.
author: Nicole D.

description:
I actually really like this bar. 
I might seem like a glitz child of the glamour moon but in all honestly, I'm pretty low key and if you're just looking for a gin shot to spruce up your night cuz you just got off work but don't wanna go home, here's the joint. 
The bartender of the night I went was all kinds of sugar and the atmosphere was totally space tiki.
If you're a humble sort with a taste for little frill but tasteful touch, come here.
author: Hannah M.

description: Buddha lounge is an inexpensive dive bar in Chinatown/FiDi. They have buddha beers, in bottles shaped like buddha. It tastes like Heineken in my opinion. The bartender is a funny guy. We played the "lie or die" dice game, which I won't even try to explain on here. He explained how to play, but we needed a practice run before we got the game going. It could be complicated if you are in the midst of the night's fun, but it's quick to follow along. The end result of this game is that the loser buys a round of beers for everyone, and it will never be forgotten who lost. It was a fun night overall and there are several other bars in the area to do the Chinatown bar crawl type of thing. Buddha Lounge is on the lists of best dive bars in SF, so I would agree, it is a place you have to try out if you are in the city.
author: Jaime F.

description:
Update 1 yr later: came back her during a business trip for MaiTais made with Ng Ka Py from Hong Kong (from Hong Kong is important because the bartender said so.. I trust her).
Made some new friends.. and it's 2pm on a Thursday. Mrs. Lee is Korean and she's and awesome person. It's a dive bar.. but it's a great one and the people who come here.. are based on the Yelp reviews and locals  I  this place. Will update next year again if not sooner.
author: Ellejah B.

description: Omg loved this place! Great place! Great prices! Cash only but worth it! We had like 15 people but didn't spend a lot!
author: Wendy A.

description: Great spot to stop for drink in SF, cooler bartender and better drinks than across the street. Very laid back and seems more authentic. Def worth an Uber ride to check out. Don't even know what the martini was, the great bartender made it based on what we said we liked.
author: Frank T.

description:
Great little spot! Loved the vibe and also drinks were cheap.

The atmosphere is very relaxed and a cozy feel. Lightning is great for bug of friends or even a date . Would definitely go back when in San Fran.
author: Warren W.

description:
Cash Only

$5 wells and beers
Super Divey
Jukebox to play your tunes 
Seating is limited and fills up fast 

Overall Thoughts

Come for the cheap drinks
author: Eddie W.

description: Very nice place, I would definitely recommend for tourists the locals are so nice!!! The drinks are all across the board great beer!!! The owner was working he was a  very personable guy!!!
author: Jasmine H.

description: Dive bar with crazy mix of locals and tourists. Don't ask for anything more complicated than a beer or maybe jack and coke. Free pretzels as there should be.
author: Jay D.

description: Convenient place to stop on Sunday in between shopping and dim sum. The same bartenders (I believe the couple are the owners) are always there and serve strong, reasonably priced drinks. The jukebox is nice touch and on Sundays, they have football on. Great dive bar in the heart of Chinatown.
author: Mally S.

description: They were showing the superbowl. Tv is small but that's ok. Closes at 6pm on Sunday so we couldn't finish the game. Seems family owned. I still like this place
author: may q.

description:
Great local vibe. Best game of dice in town!
Perfect place for a low key HH stop during the week or a quick stop before heading out on Fridays
author: Peter K.

description: Super-fun little place with wicked-strong drinks. Much of what we drank, I am unable to pronounce the name of (partially because of the strength of said drinks!). As a bonus, clean restrooms...yeah! It may seem like you are going down to your death, but nope, just a pee spot.
author: Greg H.

description: Mark is the heart and soul of this spot. Buddha beer, games and jokes is all about this spot. Love this place as well as all my buddies.
author: Eugene V.

description: Bartender was friendly. Dropped by for a few beers and got what we wanted! Very tiny bar in the middle of Chinatown area. We came in the middle afternoon so it was dead. Definitely a dive bar...Cash only!!!
author: Saynatry P.

description: Its a dive bar. Casual atmosphere, decent chairs, fair prices. If the bald Chinese bartender is working ask him about his tea.
author: Will L.

description:
A real hole in the wall dive bar in Chinatown. There are three things here that I'd recommend checking out if you happen to be in the neighborhood and don't have any plans.

First, the Buddha beer is mildly entertaining. Pretty average beer that comes in a green Buddha shaped bottle. Nothing that will rock your world, but it's the small things in life, right? Second, they have a Chinese herbal liquor that will knock your socks off. Not sure what it's called, but it comes in a bottle that only has Chinese labels on it. Doing a shot is like doing an alcoholic version of the cinnamon challenge.

Lastly, you have to try to make some conversation with Mark, the bartender. The guy always has some crazy stories, some of which I hope are made up. Never had a dull time here, mostly because engaging with him is always very entertaining.
author: Michael S.

description: Cool bar with a jukebox. Nice for downtown SF in Chinatown. Hate that it is a cash only bar. ATM fee was $5. Kind of a rip off. Met two cool chicks there and partied the rest of the night. Definitely worth a pop in just bring your own money.
author: Pugilistmuaythai ..

description: You don't understand, this is the best dive bar ever. After a long day walking we ducked in for a beer. Four beers later we were still there. Laid back and beer was cold. Am kinda mad I didn't pick up a T shirt !!!
author: Theodore O.

description: by far one of our top 3 favorite true dive bars ever!!!always a banging time!great bartenders!good prices!after dinner & the san francisco symphony or a show go here for a kick back, low key,fun people,good way to end the night early am, before eating some wonderful chinese food in china town. we go every time we go to san francisco,which is every 6 weeks or so. oh,bring cash though!this place is the jam!
author: Carmen B.

description: Best service came here after the massive let down at Li Po bar. And let me tell you the Tokyo tea was so good and strong it took us over an hour to finish it lol. Mark was amazing and very hospitable here. Def will come back and the drinks are worth every penny.
author: VANESSA H.

description:
This spot is a gem in Chinatown! Discovered this place while walking by and man, this place gets packed. I came here on Chinese New Year with a group of friends to take a break from all the festivities that was happening on the streets. We all ordered Mai Tai because that's what the bartender recommended. Let's just say you'll get the bank for your buck, they definitely do not skimp out on the alcohol. Although this bar is a bit small, the vibes was very upbeat; there's a digital jukebox inside! This bar is for sure on my list when in Chinatown. 

By the way, it's CASH ONLY! And if you need to use the bathroom, let the bartenders know because they have to buzz you in to go downstairs.
author: Rochelle G.

description: As a visitor from the east coast I found this place online as a cool bar to check out. Really loved the dive bar scene and the Buddha beer. Perfect to just sit and have a couple beers and relax. It's worth a stop if you're visiting Chinatown in San Francisco.
author: Kevin A.

description:
I've never had this much fun at a dive bar before! If you are bar hopping around Chinatown, this MUST be one of your stops. It's a small bar but not too popular, so perfect for bringing a few friends over. I didn't expect to stay for very long at first, but the bartender Mark is absolutely hilarious. At first I was annoyed because he only likes to pay attention to the section of the bar closest to the front door, but after a few drinks, calling him over didn't bother me. Plus he needs to buzz you into the underground restroom, so don't be shy to speak up.

Cocktails are pretty good. Wide variety of beers, including the iconic Buddha shaped beer bottle. I was even curious about all the Asian bottles of whiskey strewn across the back counter. But the true prize is getting to play Chinese dice games with Mark. Ask him to teach you Liar's Dice or 1-4-24. You will have a blast and even make some friends on the other side of the bar like I did! Great bonding experience, and I'm totally coming back and bringing more friends to experience Buddha Lounge.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Third stop on a Chinatown bar crawl. It was Friday, August 7th around 8pm. We stopped by for one drink.

The drink of choice? Jameson! Washed it down with a water back. The bartender was really cool and I really liked the vibe of the bar. Cool place to drop by for one drink or even hang out for a couple of rounds. Very mellow.

Another cash only bar, so remember to bring some money!
author: Elena N.

description:
"It was a hot and sweaty afternoon, the kind of afternoon that makes you see things... dicey things" 

There's no way I would have ever found this place if it wasn't for my bud, Ruggy. He lived in the city for quite awhile and has a great sense for weird spots and amazing deals, like three-dollar pizzas! But that's a tale for another review.  

A large group of us wandered through the streets of Chinatown for bit before coming to Buddha Lounge. Is it fancy? Not in the slightest. Do they have a bathroom? Yes, but it's in the basement of what feel like a scene out of "Deer Hunter". Do they have three-penis whiskey? Yes, but they were all out during my trip. Bummer

My friends and I ended owning the jukebox and playing 1-4-24 for about two hours. 1-4-24 is a dice game, in which you roll dice in hopes to get 24, but you also have to have a 1 and a 4 in your dice arsenal... you know what, just Google it. Beyond dice games and three-penis whiskey, it's pretty much a dive bar that look like something out of, "Full Metal Jacket", "Platoon" or pretty much any psychologically messed war movie of the same vane.   

The bartender here is also pretty amazing, but be careful, this guy is 1-4-24 champ and he will get at least three of your five dollars. Buddha Lives!
author: Nate M.

description:
You know what? I'm gonna go ahead and disagree with my fellow Yelp Community Manager pals who've visited this spot with me or before me. I don't find the bathrooms creepy at all. IN fact, with the metal cage blocking the entrance to the basement that you must have someone buzz you in to go down - I felt safer in a restroom than I have in years.

Then again once you let a creepy dude or gal into the caged basement of hell, and you're down there - all bets are off. This is either the safest basement bathroom or fresh toture if you get stuck down there. 

But enough about my personal nightmares... Buddha Lounge Buddhay!!!

The drinks are cheap, and Mark is a goddamn riot (I love a dive bar bartender who isn't afraid to tell you off with a smile on his face - insta buds!) Plus after losing my shirt playing dice I needed a laugh. That Mark, he's a sly mofo, he acts like a victim and then BOOM, drops the hammer and wins out on dice every single time.

Drinks drank, dollars lost, good times all around - Def-o a new fave spot in SF's illustrious Chinatown!
author: Kris U.

description: Cute little place only stopped in for a quick drink, bartender was nice and gave us popcorn
author: Shannon F.

description:
For my money, MaiTais at Buddha Lounge beat LiPo -- cool dive-bar vibe is better, too . . .

PROS: Corner of the street locale, good for a quick in-out adult beverage if you're on a pub crawl; decent jukebox; decent pours -- I like the taste of alcohol in my adult beverages

CONS: Cash only -- but nearly every bar in CTown seems to be cash only

We liked the Buddha . . . tasty MaiTais, friendly service and a good location.

Cheers!
RL
author: Rich S.

description: Bartender: Mark? Was visibly a bit tipsy but entertaining the patrons on Saturday 9/2.  I was with my sister and brother-in-law and we thought we had already paid up. Bartender said that we had and smiled, but apparently was joking.  We started to walk out and he yelled that we needed to pay.  We said we thought we had, and apparently he took this as an insult to him, the bar, and to his race. My sister gave him $40 to pay up and he took it.  We didn't know this until after.  He kept screaming at my BIL about how we were trying to cheat him of money and we were racist, etc.  We kept trying to just give him the cash we owed ($35).  He ripped my BIL's watch off of his wrist, and said now we owe him $50.  Then he said we could take it outside, and he was going to slit my BIL's throat.  No. Joke. We told him we just wanted the watch back.  He went to his register to grab it, slammed it down, and told us to "get the fuck out."  So we paid the guy $80 in total for a $35 tab, he broke his watch, and we left feeling there was nothing we could do.  This guy needs to be fired and possibly seek help.  A real scary incident and damper on an otherwise great night.
author: Becca B.

description: Cool place!!! Great place to film a movie. The decor is awesome the old look suits this place and door outside is awesome. I mean the entrance!
author: Cristian G.

description: Another dive bar in Chinatown, though a bit bigger and more well lit than Bow Bow Cocktail Lounge. The mai tai is rather odd, with a splash of their "3-penis liquor" in there. A little underwhelming and not as grungy as you'd expect.
author: Christina S.

description: Shout out to Mark. One of the funniest and easiest guys to get along with. Cheap drinks and a whole lot of fun
author: Daniel C.

description: Great place in Chinatown. Solid bartender (Mark) always entertaining. Always take out of town guests here and it never fails.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Best Mai Tai in Existence. Best Bartender Ever. Most Creative Beer Bottle.

The Mai Tai isn't for the faint of heart. It's a concoction of pure liquor w/ a splash of juice. I advise drinking a max of 2 in a sitting, cause on a scale of 1 to 5 they will just wreck your night. Best of all it's like $6 and just amazing.

The bartender Mark, brings a level of service that I have yet to see from other bartenders. He is just hilarious, on-point, and professional. He recommended a great place to eat around the corner. And definitely the #1 reason I am coming back.

Anytime someone comes here they should order the buddha beer, just because the bottle is awesome and the beer isn't half bad.

Anyone stopping by in SF, stop by here and you won't regret it.
author: Izzy L.

description: this place is the bomb. nestled in the heart of Chinatown is a good ole dive bar with a local feel. I hear the Japanese whisky is a must try!
author: Shelly B.

description: First trip to Buddha! Strolled over after work, to spread out our happy hour area. We all got the Buddha beers, and the nice bartender washed our bottles and put a cap on them so we could carry them out. They have one of those new type of fancy juke boxes in the front, if you don't look you'll miss it and be confused about the random array of music types, mixed with long periods of silence. Will Def come back to try the Chinese Mai tai!
author: Lindsey P.

description: Nice people, inexpensive drinks, no frills, what you see is what you get! Great location for nearby dinner and dim sum.
author: Latrice J.

description: Loooove coming to Buddha Lounge! They have a jukebox for music selection, variety of drinks, and the BEST bartender, Mark!! Mark is probably the only reason why I would even venture into Chinatown. Go to Buddha Lounge and strike a convo with Mark, you would not be disappointed. :)
author: Anj H.

description:
Nice dive bar on corner of Grant and Washington?

in any case, I normally go to Li Po across the way, but this place opens a bit earlier

they have started carrying coors light, so that is a good thing

this bar tends to have more tourists than Li Po, probably because it's location makes it easier to stumble into
usually quite a bit louder and livelier crowd in here than Li Po too, so if that's your thing, then this is the bar to choose!

found that its great to grab a couple beers at corner by door and just sit and watch the characters that come to visit Chinatown.....just like watching reality TV!

fully stocked bar with many choices, not too expensive for san Francisco either, so if you need a rest and a drink in Chinatown, this is not a bad choice!
author: Ken L.

description: Such a fun spot! Total dive, but with little touches that make it a solid bar. Play some dice, have a goof with Mark tending bar or put on some swanky tunes on the digital jukebox. Drinks are cheap, so the rounds keep coming. A great pre-game spot before you hit the town or after you've crushed a bag of dumplings. Do it!
author: Drew A.

description: Me and my friend from Ukraine were trying to visit the best dive bar in Chinatown. There were a lot of people in, but not crowded. And it was to far before closure. But the bartender was so rude and just didn't let us in. Too bad for the best dive bar.
author: Roman O.

description:
You say Mark, I say Mak. Or Mock. Or something. Anyways, this place is an absolute gem. It doesn't fit a ton of people, but there are always fun people inside, and Mock makes this place 10,000 times better. Make sure you play one of the two dice games he's totally willing to teach people. And know that if you play against him, he'll win.

If you're feeling adventurous, try the weird Chinese whiskey stuff in the weird porcelain bottle and chase it with a Buddha Beer. I guarantee you'll love that you tried it, and absolutely despise the taste.

Wanna use the restroom? Have Mock buzz you downstairs, then wonder what goes on in that large room behind the gate. But seriously, this place is great. A unique experience to be sure.
author: Akshay A.

description: Best dive bar in China town.  Excellent digital juke box, great selection of beers, very friendly bartenders, and fun patrons.  A stroll through China town isn't complete without a stopover to this watering hole.
author: Greta R.

description:
Super dive. I love liars dice and the Buddha beer bottles. 

Bartender provided peanuts / popcorn.  Pretty much a basic small little dive that I will return to frequently!

By the way, play Liars Dice against the bartender and tell me if you win ;).
author: Trevor M.

description:
GREATEST DIVE BAR in Chinatown.  Mark, the bartender (we're on first name basis, because we cool), was a kind gentlemen.  My friends and I landed from LA, and decided to do a late night tour of Chinatown, so we stopped by here to get hydrated.  It was a splendid experience, Mark even gave us extra olives.  Good man.  

Bathroom: let's talk about this.  So I felt like Andy from Shawshank Redemption.  Every time I had to use the ladies' room, Mark had to buzz you in through what looked like an electric barbwired door and you went downstairs into the abyss.  Scary, but adventurous...
author: Niyera D.

description: I like this place. A simple (dive?) bar with a great bartender. He knows what a bartender is supposed to do (talk to his clients and suggest the best drinks). I can see why this bar continues to stay in business.
author: George S.

description:
Lucky Buddha beer is the drink of choice at this particular establishment. I Have never seen this beer before and will probably never see it again. Buddha being the universal symbol of good fortune, one would think this would be a sign of great things to come this evening but my luck, this fateful night, has proven otherwise. As my attention was devoted to the beer my attention wasn't placed where it should've been, on my wallet. After finishing one and about to order another I realized my mistake. My wallet had been stolen. 

One might be asking themselves why one would give a 5 star rating to an establishment where their wallet was stolen but the bartender was more concerned with my stolen wallet than I was. He was very nice and offered the next round in the house. And for that they have earned themselves a 5 star rating. 

And who knows it does seem fairly serendipitous that my wallet would be stolen while drinking the only Buddha beer I've ever had. Maybe it'll turn out for the best in the end.
author: Ted H.

description:
I am pissing myself at how fun this place is.  I was taught liar's dice which I lost every time resulting in my drinking shot after shot after shot.

Simple bar which is a bit beat up.  The kind of bar I love and could sit at all day playing old school music and drinking and losing and drinking and losing to liar's dice.

The owner, I at least believe she was the owner, is pretty funny.  I think she wouldn't be that hard to tick off but she was very nice to me since I paid timely.
author: Chris M.

description: 98% food safety scorecard - I'm in - not sure where the food is though. Bartender is fabulous. Restroom is high tech keyless entry and similar to Blair Witch Project. I love it here.
author: Ronda D.

description:
I am not from SF, but was in town for work and thought I would check Chinatown out like I do in every city. I am not Chinese, but I lived with a Chinese guy once, so I'm pretty good, also I am really good a Street Fighter, I digress.

I walked into Buddha bar and ordered a round of drinks for 2 of my best friends. These guys are great, except for Stefan, that dude is the worst. 

After a few drinks I had to urinate, so the bartender buzzed me into the basement area....(I know, why would the basement have the same security as a New York City apartment) and went to the bathroom. Before I could get back up the steps the lights started flickering and a dragon came out of the ground. At first, I was like "you know, I knew I would see a dragon today, just one of those days", then I was like "holy smokes, a dragon". After the dragon killed me, (I was grossly under prepared to fight a dragon. I mean he could barely move, since we were in a basement, but what am I going to do, punch a dragon, yeah good luck with that Buddhay {Pronounce that buddy and it's clever}) I woke up and was sitting upstairs the entire time, I had just went on myself!

Buddha Lounge has the best acid..
author: Joshua L.

description: A super chill place with a good selection on the juke box. The best thing is the bartender/ stand up comedian/ competitive drinker peddling a Buddha tee shirt that gives you super sexual powers. Cash only.
author: Andy W.

description:
Stopped in for a quick drink before strolling China town, SF. It's a small dive bar that offers free popcorn and a juke box. Bartender lady is friendly and quick to make drinks! Not my type of bar but pretty awesome for quick drinks. 

Bathroom is located down stairs in the basement, pretty scary and creepy. You'd also need to get buzzed in by the bartender.
author: Fan V.

description:
Was having a great time at this bar last night and was having a great time -- service was excellent, the Buddha Beers were a great price and everything was super great.

After I ordered my beer I had to go to the little boys room, so I took the one bathroom key, unlocked the door and went down to the basement.  It was a pretty normal basement - with boxes and cases of beer, so I found the bathroom and used it.  When I came out there was an old Chinese man in a straw hat was standing there, and all the boxes were gone.  

Confused, I begged his pardon to get by.  Instead of moving, he stared at me and started shouting in Chinese.  I started backing up and turned to make sure I didn't trip, but when I looked back he was gone, and all the boxes were back in the basement!

I assume he just left, but when I went back upstairs they told me I in fact had the ONLY bathroom key and no one else could have used the door!  Super spooky.

Long story short -- great bar, but haunted.
author: Stefan S.

description:
SVU on TV, sign of a fabulous bar, right?
And I am with Ruggy J, creepiest bathroom in SF for sure. I am pretty sure this was featured on a scene of SVU, I mean you have to be buzzed into the basement. Yep. Typical Chinese dive bar, yep. 

The Mai Tais were extremely strong and got the job done!
Cash only. Go in a group =)
author: Colleen B.

description:
FRONT ROW VIEW OF CHINESE NEW YEAR'S EVE CELEBRATIONS

Step outside the front door here on CNYE and get ready to put on your protective eyewear. It's red paper madness out front and most of the crowd has a lighter in their hand.  "*Flick*flame*boom*" say the firecrackers!

For a break from the deafening, smokey air, step inside the Buddle Lounge. It's a small seating area with stools pulled up at the bar and also at a shelf along the wall, with a narrow pathway between these spots. You can't fit a lot of people in here, but I imagine it's not quite as packed most other nights of the year.

We make a point to stop in here and across the street, every year as we celebrate! The bottled bear wasn't super expensive but I wouldn't call it cheap. It was $5ish? if I remember correctly. Guess that's about average. 

Good tunes were playin'! Some 80s love song came on and I let my vocals go free! La la la la la. Friends were probably thankful for all the noise outside at this point, and suggested we leave the bar. Good idea, friends, before I really start singing!
author: Amy S.

description:
A Chinatown SF dive bar known for 2 drinks:

1.) Chinese Whiskey Mai Tai. It comes in a Chinese canister and tastes herbally/flowery. It tastes very weak, but is a creeper drink and is stronger than you think. Worth it for a bar crawl / on the way to North Beach 3 blocks away.
2.) Buddha Beer - light Heineken-like beer in a unique Buddha shaped bottle. Fun novelty, but it's not that great a beer.
author: Chuck N.

description: So fun! Great music from the jukebox and Momma Lee is awesome!  Good spot for a cold drink and some fantastic people!
author: Joy G.

description: Walked in, felt like home. CASH ONLY. The bartender is pretty great. We were schooled on the proper way to pump gas whilst in Stockton. (Butch it up, men.) Heard the best music evah. (Who'd have guessed jimi played Chinatown?) Learned the wiley ways of Seattle schoolteachers. (Bitterness and the long lens approach) And knocked over the same gaddamned drink twice. Which meant it was time to go home. Til next time...
author: Em L.

description: Cute little place in Chinatown.  The bartender was having a great time when I was there.  We ordered 3 cocktails for 19$ so Im not complaining.  Like many other mentioned this is cash only.  You can do some great people watching at this place- especially on a hot Saturday afternoon!
author: Kate F.

description: Ms. Lee makes you feel at home... Most fun I've had on a trip!! Love her so very much!
author: Jeanette D.

description: I've been here twice for a quick drink and haven't really seen anything in this place that really makes it stand out from any other bars in the area. It's definitely a dive bar, it's really dark and gloomy inside, the smell of stale cigarettes lingers through the air, and prices never match quality. I'd come here to grab a quick buddha beer or a shot of whiskey, but it's definitely not a place that I want to spend very much time at.
author: Joseph A.

description:
This is one of my all-time favorites bars in San Francisco. It's a straight up room with a long bar that serves liquor--no bells and whistles. It's in Chinatown, close enough to the Financial District, Downtown, and North Beach. It's hole-in-wall yet on the corner of a semi-busy street. The glowing neon lighting is inviting. The bartender Mark is a fun smartass. The drinks are cheap. They have dice in cups here to play whatever possible games (like Liar's dice and 1-4-24). I learned how to play 1-4-24 here--pretty fun.

When I went there was this really creepy dude who just bought some water and stared HARD at this 2 Asian girls that become part of our group for like 2 hours. He straight up STARED at them very creepily for 2 hours--no shame. Then he tried to follow my friends and I home. You may find this fellow here--beware and watch your things.
author: Marlon T.

description: Great little stop in China town. Super low key and went here a few times. The bartenders were all very friendly.
author: Todd W.

description:
Yayy!!! Another SF weekend trip. The reviews in SF keep on coming...


- Locale Destination -
It's on Grant Ave and Washington St in Chinatown, San Francisco. 
Bartender (Chinese) was friendly. Very dark inside, the lamps are very Chinese in red, iron cage got to be opened by the bartender for toilet usage downstairs... 
I'm not a regular bar hopper. So I'm not so sure about the classifications of bar like Dive bar, sports bar etc. Here's definitely the bar you bring the one you've known really well or friends, not a date. Dingy inside and sort of shabby & scary "Chinatown" atmosphere outside at night... 

Cash only for bar?!?! It's very unheard of such a thing in OC at least. You don't see that unless it's a little Asian food places... But almost all places in Chinatown are cash only. I'm sure they pay tax... 
 

- Gluttony Expedition - 
2 weak drinks (with a tiny glass) for $12?!? TOTAL RIP OFF!!

Even in OC, you can get a lot stronger drinks for cheaper price tag. Seriously!! I'm Asian and can't take a booze much. In OC and LA, I always got to ask "please make it weak". It still comes out with "strong" one for me. But if I didn't, the drink would be way too strong and I couldn't drink. (I'm very cheap/economical when it comes to booz ;p)

Vodka & soda: Very weak. 
Midori like Chinese liquor with orange & pineapple juice: Very weak. 


- Conqueror's Deduction -
I don't understand the reviews by SF yelpers here.
I attended an Elite event (East side) , and all the SF yelpers were super cool.
If people think here's cheap, they must be super rich or oblivious ignorant...
$6 for ONE too sissy and tiny drink is a total rip off.
You see $15 to 20 drink in LA but they offer a cool vibe, atmosphere or whatever at least. Here's not the case....

I'm not so familiar with SF, but this is definitely not cheap for watery drink and Cash only. I'm sure these "Cash Only" places help our economy and ridiculous amount of deficit in CA.
author: Akiko I.

description:
This will be my go-to bar whenever I come to San Francisco. Girlfriend and I rolled in around 9pm, sat down and asked him to give us two special drinks.... Booooommm hit the spot!!! Strong drink and heavy hand!!
Then we ordered two more special to sip on drinks... Another heavy hand pour...
Drinks were great, atmosphere was great, everyone is friendly, bartender treats you like a friend.. To get respect you have to earn respect is what he believes in.
To top it off after all the drinks and shots the price was amazing.. I will be coming back!!
author: Alex Y.

description:
For those that are keeping score at home, I search far and wide in SF for the greatest of great rocky bar stool establishment. Well welcome to the Buddah Lounge. You're going there to meet Mark, the vibrant tender that brings the energy and uniqueness to light the dark walls. I think that's what everyone is there for. A man that brings you one liners that only a great comedian can provide, but he isn't even trying. That's the Buddah Lounge. 

A place where you can drink amongst people that are in it for the same thing but remembering to check the ego at the door or else Mark will make you in a single roll of the dice. Martini, whiskey,
Asian mystery concoction, or a Buddah beer - you have to cap the night with one. Just do you!
author: Colin H.

description: Awesome little dive bar with locals and a buzz-you-in restroom. Everyone was pretty friendly and the drinks were fine. Definitely an experience worth having. I'll be going back next time I'm in town.
author: Greg K.

description:
If you like real dive bars, this is your place in Chinatown!

I was going to go to Red's, but decided to try this place because of the song that was playing as I was walking by (James - Sit Down. how cool is that?!) It was 4pm on a Saturday.  There were a few tourists and a few locals.  I got a chuckle that a Chinese American tourist assumed she knew Chinese and tried to converse with her.  She replied, "sorry I don't know Chinese, English?"  (Kind of funny since we are in the center of Chinatown.) Turns out she's Korean. Nice lady!

I didn't stay long, but long enough to have a Buddha beer ($5), play 3 songs on the Internet jukebox ($1), and converse with everyone in the bar (all 5 people). Both the bartender and patrons were all really nice.  I'm going back here when I visit SF again.

Oh, in case you were wondering I played:
Billy Idol - Eyes Without a Face
The Cars - Let The Good Times Roll
The Clash - Overpowered By Funk
author: Jammy S.

description:
Totally dirty, grimey and dusty. 

But the cool tunes on the jukebox (heck, a jukebox that actually works!), friendly bartender and a scary way to the bathroom (why is there a big, steel gate on the way down to the basement??) sounds fun to me. 

Hey, I lower my standards a bit when I'm in Chinatown.
author: Janice C.

description: Dive bars are my favorite but this is in fact the Diviest bar I've been to. Very interesting/scary crowd. Place smelled like ramen & pee. Bartenders were very nice & we had the Buddha beer, comes in a cool bottle but tastes like a coors light . We also had the shot that's supposed to make men horny ha! It was extremely strong, tastes like jagër & rubbing alcohol
author: Jenn B.

description:
Awesome dive bar right in the heart of China Town. The bartender was very nice and he interacted with all of his patrons. I can see why this place is critically acclaimed as "one of the top 33 dive bars in the US!" 

The drinks are cheap as well. Go here for a quick drink!
author: Richard T.

description:
I can't think of a better way...my mother would disagree...to spend a Sunday Fun-Day. Liar's Dice and Buddha beers in hand, pulling up a chair with a handful of friends at Buddha Lounge. 

Amidst the chaos of the Lunar Festival, I sought refuge this past weekend in a reliable Chinatown oasis. Mark and Lee always know how to make passers-by feel welcome. We even got free Tsingtao fortune cookie-shaped bottle openers.

If you're anything like me, after an hour or two passes by, you and your friends will have done one or all of the following:
A. Played Liar's Dice, repeatedly forcing one unlucky friend to buy rounds for the group.
B. Take that friend to the point of ordering Fireball whisky for the bunch, instead of beer. "You didn't say what round I had to buy."
C. Eventually having that friend spotting a strange foreign looking Chinese herbal whisky and having the group risk GI unpleasantries for the rest of the night.

Have fun, and remember...don't drink and drive!
author: Nick W.

description: Mark is my favorite bartender in SF. The place is always hopping. The music rocks. The drinks are cheap. All Hail Mark and the Buddha Lounge!
author: Charlie B.

description: After spending the day in San Francisco walking without an agenda, my buddy and I stumbled into Buddha Lounge.  Perfect dive bar with a great vibe, inexpensive drinks and a very nice bartender.
author: Noel K.

description:
The dopest bar in the entire neighborhood and personally (on this side of the city) weekdays especially. Looking for a low key place to chill with friends. Have a date? Chilling with friends? This is the place. The place to have great talks and laughs. Enjoy the atmosphere and the Buddha beers. 

Cheers.
author: Rob G.

description: favorite dive bar with the greatest dive-bar bartender - Mark - who takes being rude to an elegant and appreciated level.  I love everything about this bar.  But I prefer if you don't listen to me and help keep it from getting too popular.
author: reza n.

description:
This bar lost all it's true dive bar charm when they replaced the hole in the ground that used to be the men's toilet with an actual toilet.  No offense

And... while I am happy to report that the bartender has been sober for close to a decade, that fact also means there's not a hammered bartender pouring our drinks anymore.  Yes, there really is only one bartender, and he's been it's bartender for at least 20 years.  Now, I'm not saying the drinks aren't over-poured, I'm just saying that they used to be more over-poured.  

However, the Buddha will always be one of the diviest bars in Nor Cal.  Between the worn outness, stale booze smell, kitschy Chinese-American mural and decor, not to mention the gate and basement bathrooms, it will  forever be a dive bar.

It's all that and a bag of chips!

Enjoy
author: Celia H.

description: Great service. The little old lady and the littler older man really wanted you to get what you want even if they don't speak English. They're famous for their Chinese Mai Thai and for 9$ you had better order it even if it feels casually racist to do so. They either use Tiger Wine or Chinese Whiskey,  mattering in if you all my friend's Mom. Cool Buddha shaped beer bottles. Divey and fun.
author: Steven C.

description: i've not usualllyyy a dive bar kinda girl, but this place was solid. mark the bartender is super nice and approachable, and made us laugh. you can play dice, catch up with friends, get wasted, etc. etc. cash only though, so bring yo dolla billls!
author: Christina L.

description:
Disgusting and overpriced Mai Tai


Went with a few friends and ordered Mai Tai's today for everyone. The staff are nice enough but the Mai Tai's made us all want to hurl. They have some undrinkable Chinese liqueur in the Mai Tai instead of rum! And they are $9 each!
author: Laurence S.

description: Went in on a whim and what a good decision. Had their Buddha beer (it's okay) and the hubby had their three penis whiskey. Great service and a very homey place. Had a great vibe and watched the bar tender (owner??) play a dice game with a fellow customer. This felt like I was a home at a friends get together. We came to visit from LA and her and her customer talked to us about the little hole in the wall things to do. What a great feel of an authentic china town bar.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Very cool entrance but kind of sad and divey when you're inside.
Good spot to get a drink on Christmas eve (it never closes).
author: Ric S.

description:
I knew it was going to be good when I walked in to this empty bar around noon and the bartender was resting her head against the bar taking a nap.

This place is pretty nice though and after she woke up she was a very pleasant host.

When I return to SF I'll definitely be back here.
author: Brian C.

description:
A Buddah bar, how you and I have had some great times together.  You are the dive of my heart, the beer of my eye.  

Back long ago during one fleet week my friend and I were in the Buddah drinking Chinese Beer, with sailors from Italy, watching Arabic TV in the greatest of American cities.  You can't make that up.

Put your dollars into the jukebox and let the rock play.  Have a Tsing Tao or four and feel the zen flow over you.  Or maybe that is the need to use the restroom.  You'll need your hiking boots for that one.  Get buzzed through the gate....travel down the stairs....through the underground tunnels...back up a set of stairs.  NOW you have found your place of bliss.  

Back up to the bar you go for more hydration.  

And what memory of the Buddah would not be complete without the great memory of taking my future wife here on our very first date.
author: Charles R.

description:
This is what it feels like when doves cry. 

A tiny slip of an Asian dive bar with 10 seats, bartender straight out of Big Trouble In Little China, and an eight buck Mai Tai the size of my damn head. 

I wonder if whoever owns this joint knows they;re going to have to physically remove me from the premises to get me out. Or just feed me a few more Mai Tais and slop me up off the floor with a dustpan and toss me outside.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I have lived in San Francisco for most of my life, been to China town many a-times, and had many a-beers during that time.  However, this bar seemed to just...appear out of thin air.  

I walked through the front entrance with my best mates, ready to consume some delicious malty beverages.  The bartender was friendly and served us these beers shaped like Buddha.  I thought it was pretty cool...Until I realized the truth...

I went downstairs to relieve myself.  The basement was clean and well lit, full of empty beer bottles and boxes. While in the bathroom, I saw a little door in the corner and felt the need to investigate.  Upon looking inside, I saw rows and rows of buddha bottles being filled by a astral being.  I strained to look closer and noticed it was the spirit of Buddha himself filling regular beer bottles with his spirit, after which point his spirit turned to beer and the bottle turned into buddha himself.  He noticed I was watching and I freaked out! I turned to run but tripped over the toilet and hit my head on the urinal. I lay there stunned when all of a sudden Buddha comes bursting through the wall like the Kool-Aid Man "OH YEAHHHHH" and starts rolling towards me (he is really fat so it's hard for him to walk.  I picked myself off and began running back upstairs with Buddha rolling behind me (Like Indiana Jones when he's running from the big rock).  I run back upstairs, narrowly avoiding buddha who dissipated with the cool crisp air and dingy lighting of the bar. 

The Bartender looked at me and pointed to the jukebox....I slowly walked over and hesitantly looked at it.  The only artist on there was Ray Parker Jr.... I pressed play and a bunch of Disco lights came on while the Ghostbusters theme song played on repeat for an hour.  Buddha came up through the floor and danced with my friends and I.  

Just a normal Tuesday night.  Definitely a bar for an adventure.
author: Will H.

description:
Creepiest bathroom in SF? Yes.  
Most expensive High Lifes in SF? No.

Bam!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
How many stars can you give a bar?  How can you give just one?  It's a bar!  

There is alcohol.  You drink it.  If you have a good time or not, it's completely up to you.  You can't blame the bartender.  You can tell from walking in the door, this is not a fancy place.  What gave that away?  Look at the neighborhood that you're in.  You're in Chinatown.  Stop acting so stuck up.  Order a beer or a shot, or both.  Don't ask for fancy cocktails with cut fruit and paper umbrellas.  

Go there at night.  Bring a Chinese translator.  "Mok" the bartender likes to speak with a conjured up "Yan Can Cook" accent.  We all know that Martin Yan fakes the accent.  So does "Mok".  You can call him Mark.  Who knows what his real name is.  Like strippers, I'm sure "Mok" is just a stage name.  Although I would feel really weird about tipping a man named "Jasmine" or "CoCo".  

Yeah, Chinese bartenders use stage names.  Just go to one of those clip joints with a bunch of Asian girls hustling drinks, in a bar that really only needs 1 bartender, and all those bar girls will be using stage names.  Now which bars hire a bunch of girls wearing too much make-up and not enough clothing?  Hmmm..........  Surely, places like that don't really exist outside of Vietnamese coffee houses in San Jose.  "PR" joints are more of an urban legend, right?  Just like the fable of the old Korean women who bartend because they're too old to work in massage parlors, right?

"Mok" will do the same.  The rotten bastard will flirt with you, wink at you, offer back rubs, and anything else that's borderline sleazy for a big tip.  He's not to turn your back on.  Keep one eye on your wallet at all times.  You will wake up the next morning with a bad taste in your mouth, a throbbing head, a soreness likened to prison lovemaking, and no money left over.  No promises that he'll kiss you first.
author: The Boy I.

description: This is my new favorite bar in San Francisco. About 10 seats at the bar, ample standing room, a couple of dudes playing dice at the bar, chill bartender, refreshingly unpretentious SF crowd. When can I go back? Maybe tonight.
author: Mel G.

description: Randomly went to this bar because of the sign and name. It was almost two and just wanted to get out of the street since the area looks hella sketch around the bar. Walked in to use the bathroom but had to buy a drink, Which was understandable. The service was really good and the bartender hooked it up with our drinks. It was definitely worth the money. Wish we coulda bought a shirt though
author: Justin T.

description:
It's small, it's dive-y, it's Buddha lounge.

Is the bathroom a bit creepy? very likely.

Do you think it's a front for something? most definitely.

Come on in and enjoy a nice adult beverage at Buddha lounge!
author: Vince H.

description:
Must have come here on an off night, as the bar had few patrons. This is a classic BAR in it's street-attitude, dark and unruly in a fun kind of way.

Short but not so sweet. 

Beers are good and cold and fresh. The mixed drinks... not so much. My mai tai tasted like it had cranberry juice in it (that strong a flavor to distinguish from all the others) and the martini's were a little too "syrupy", even though I saw them made right in front of me.

Sound system could use improvements, as some songs playing in the background had good audio quality, while others sounded like poor copies of MP3 played on my headphones.

Again, maybe I came on an off night, but not very impressed.
author: Sonya R.

description: I saw this on a list of one of the best bars in SF, i knew it was a dive bar, but I was expecting a little more, got a Buddah beer tried to enjoy the ambiance and feel the magic, but I did not.
author: Morgan M.

description:
After what seemed like a Tuesday that was never going to end, I reluctantly dragged myself to this bar to meet up with a couple of acquaintances I'd met at some other bars from time to time.

When I walked in, it felt good, Tuesday blues were gone, good music was playing, a cold buddha beer to quench my thirst and a bit of harmless banter thrown back and forth from the mischievous bartender. Brilliant!! 

After a few, it was time to get buzzed down the stairs to the infamous loo. After going about my business, I started walking back through the empty bottles and cardboard boxes in the basement. It was eerie, and I felt like I was being watched. Up in the rafters was a bald eagle. Out of nowhere. How did it get there? The thing kept sq-waking, almost to the tune of freebird. I panicked, ran up the stairs to to retreat back to my spot at the bar with my buddha and loud-mouthed acquaintances. Man, that was a trip to the bathroom I wish to forget. 

Freedom and 'Shrooms, you win.

5 stars for the #chooseyourownadventure
author: Kristy B.

description:
DIVE time 

super small place, the lady bartender was awesome 

+ free popcorn 

Hopefully you don't have to use the restroom because it's very dungeon-like
author: Nik R.

description: Good prices bring some change because they dont play music unless you play the jukebox there was a full bar and i was the only one spending money on the jukebox while every one enjoyed my playlist no one wanted to spend a dollar to keep playing music.
author: Vic C.

description:
Wow. What in the world goes on here when no one is at the bar? Well, "bar," can be a loosely used term. Basically the purveyor and production facility for the world's largest and most potent mai thai. Essentially a small bucket of liquors tossed together to make your liver's worst enemy. Did my best to finish one. 

Also, agreeing with Ruggy J, creepiest bathroom in SF. More like dungeon access which happens to house a couple of commodes. Also, getting buzzed in through a steel gate isn't calming anyone's nerves.
author: Benjamin G.

description: Cool little no frills dive bar in China Town. Had some great conversation with the bartender about China and the new generation of Chinese youth.
author: Ry B.

description:
Exemplary Chinatown Bar!! Cash only!

The beverages mixed generously and were served so well. The new online juke box and sound system was fabulous, any song you could think of. 

Packed with site see'ers.
author: Best P.

description:
Ed M. might be my long lost brother and we don't even know it.

Apparently some of my brethren in LA Yelp mistaken him for me as he eloquently described the situation in his review of Damon's Steakhouse where hordes of female Yelpers clamored around him like a rockstar all because of mistaken identity of me. 

OK OK, I kid about one part of that story. Just won't tell you which part.

I didn't mind letting him have my fallouts or groupies because I still remembered the first time I met him and the cool gestures he had shown. 

On a afternoon of overstuffed dim sum lunch and sipping of bobba drinks at Ten Rens with a collections of misfit Yelpers both from the North and South of Fresno, we happened to upon an interesting door way.

It looked like a erecting....oh I can't really say it. You have to look at it: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/51gscyjxkVari5gK3qIsTA?select=7rwxgO7B0sIHVkOebET2wQ . I don't want to say a certain Yelper was taking massive picture of it, but if you have to know... *cough*Miak.*cough*.

Going inside of this place, a small divey looking bar encase the joint. Right off the bat, my pal was already hitting on the two KC tourist enjoying their last sobriety moment before slurring into never-ending giddy laughs. Gotta to hand to my boy Mike for that.

I had honestly never heard of the Irish Car bombs. Good Ol' Ed M. was going to introduce it to us LA Yelpers and pop our Irish Car Bomb cherries on the spot. As you can see, the mad scientist Ed  was at work mixing the drink to spite us http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/51gscyjxkVari5gK3qIsTA?select=xmRPxx7VJEyhSuGw-HZIvw . However, he decided to join us on the fun.

No need to laugh, but he did finished the Irish Car bomb faster than 5 of the other participants from LA. Two of us blamed on the nasty bobba drinks. Ha!

The place was obscure on the corner of a Chinatown. I can only imagine tourist or some thirsty fellas looking to hit that quick drink would show up at this dive of a place. It looked very interesting enough on day time.

The fact he decided to shell out the muhla and paid for our drinks while trying to show us Chinatown was a gesture that was not lost on me. So obviously I was going to let him slide on mooching off using my name sake.

Now Ed, if you do have the phone numbers of some cute Asian chick from Temple City, I expect you to turn that over to me. You know that was meant for me right? Ha!
author: Mike L.

description: This place is pretty cool if you are shopping around Chinatown and get thirsty all of a sudden. We would've stayed longer, had we known it was cash only. Nonetheless, the crowd was live and the jukebox had everything from Queen to Marvin Gaye, which was a definite perk. Don't stumble down the stairs when headed to the bathroom
author: Charley B.

description: Tried the Chinese Mai Tai & was not disappointed! It was delicious & not watered down! Definitely got me in the mood to continue exploring Chinatown. I like knowing that this place is considered a "dive bar," and I would definitely go back.
author: JM C.

description: Asks for the specialty Mai Tai, it'll do the job! So good, the bartender is very nice. I deff recommend this place to sip and relax in the midst of your touring!
author: Janessa D.

description:
Dive Bar: 

A well-worn, unglamorous bar, often serving a cheap, simple selection of drinks to a regular clientele. 

The term can describe anything from a comfortable-but-basic neighborhood pub to the nastiest swill-slinging hole.

ex: "You don't need to dress up; we're just going to the dive bar down the street. "
or
"Man, that place is such a dive bar... Don't go in unless you plan to burn your clothes afterwards."

This place is the very definition of a dive bar, and as such, deserves a 4 star review when judged  by those merits. It would be 5 stars if the drinks were cheaper and/or the place was cleaner. Some friends and I stumbled in while ambling around china town looking for food. We shot the shit with the Chinese proprietor and had a round of Jameson + sodas (it's what he was drinking); four for around $22. They were doubles, and as such, reasonably priced. He was talkative and funny in a condescending sort of way, and he recommended a restaurant that we ended up enjoying very much, so 4 stars it is. 

Cash only and there is no beer on tap. There are dice cups, microwave popcorn and futball on the telly though.
author: Logan J.

description: We tried Li Po across the street but it was not amazing as Anthony Bourdain claimed. So we went to Bhudda Lounge. Much better and inexpensive.
author: Allison G.

description: Located in the heart of Chinatown, This is a small neighborhood dive bar w/ cheap stiff drinks. Marc/Mark? The bartender is a great guy. 2013 Jukebox to play whatever your into.
author: Séamus C.

description:
This is my regular bar. I don't know if the cocktails are any good, I only drink whisky. I DO know that the other regulars are fun, Mark is the best bartender in San Francisco, and I have met some wonderfully interesting people there.
I was going every night, but then I had to get up, ever again. 

Why is everyone surprised by cash only? How else are you to play dice?
author: John X.

description: Dive bar in Chinatown with a jukebox and cheap drinks. What more could you want on a random Friday night? Cash only.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Probably my favorite bar in SF. It's a little hole-in-the-wall place on Grant in the bustling part of Chinatown, but when you walk inside it's suddenly dark and quiet. Great crowd of regulars with good jukebox tastes. We randomly encountered a bunch of Michigan expats, which was fun.

This is a liquor and beer kind of place... don't come in expecting fancy cocktails. The standard seems to be Jameson and Tsingtao, and we stuck to that.

Good times!

One word of warning: NO CREDIT CARDS! There are a couple of bank ATMs a block north on Grant, you'll want to fill up on greenbacks before settling in at the Buddha.
author: Dave T.

description: Open during the day, with an eclectic crowd of patrons. Beer was decently priced.
author: John H.

description: Easy dive bar in Chinatown. Jukebox. Friendly bartender. Cash only. Buddah shaped beer bottles. GREAT view of Chinatown and the Transamerica building @ night.
author: Wendy K.

description:
I think it was our old pal Siddhartha who said: "Enlightenment can be found after a few drinks at Buddha Lounge." 

Located on what I call "The Golden Pathway" in Chinatown (that part of Grant Ave where this place, Li Po, Golden Gate Bakery, and Empress of China co-exist), this is certainly one of thee best dive bars in the around. 

What makes it so great? Well, like most dives, it's small, dark, the regulars are colorful, and it has a killer jukebox. But unique to Chinatown dives, the spirited bartender will often persuade you to try some unknown Asian liquor that tastes similar to rocket fuel and will send you into orbit. 

Ask him for some dice and play and gamble on the bar. You may lose a few dollars (like I did), or buy too many rounds of shots (like I did), but it always amounts to a rollicking good time.
author: Christina S.

description: We were looking for a place in China town where we could sit down, get a drink and re-group. We were standing on the corner of Grant Ave looking in & wondering if Buddha would be the place. We were waved in by a happy group of people; we asked if they served spirits the patrons said, "no problem!" The little place was packed & we immediately made friends with half the people there. Everyone had a great attitude. Drinks were stiff and cheap & "Lee" the bartender was friendly. Thank goodness we found this place, or actually it found us. After a few drinks and good advice we headed back into the wonderful China town district in search of adventure.
author: Rain Greg J.

description:
Buddha Lounge has some cool art work, Mark was my Bartender.Ask for his mixed drinks, he'll make it stiff for you. the rest room is downstairs and its pretty damn creepy.

Happy Drinking!
author: Jay K.

description: If you're with a large group and it's your chore to choose the bar, this certainly makes for one of the more interesting / unexpected choices you could make.  The location is exotic, being in the heart of Chinatown (how often do you go to bars in Chinatown?) and the night I was there it was basically empty so we owned the place.  Dice are available if you're into that.  I go with the Buddha Beer (mostly because then I can say I'm having a Buddha Beer at the Buddha Bar).
author: Benjamin K.

description: Great bar to grab some drinks walking through China Town.
author: Scott C.

description: It's a typical dive bar smack in the heart of Chinatown. They're cash only with a very cool digital jukebox. Drinks were nice and strong. All of the patrons were happy and singing to the music.
author: Jenny G.

description:
What I like about this place is that it is unassuming, serves cheap drinks, and patrons will often be playing pirates' dice - which the bartender will happily start a game with you (as long as you're willing to bet money). Makes for an interesting night.

A few cons: it's kind of in the middle of Chinatown, which is not necessarily the most popular destination to go out in. Also, the bathroom is downstairs in the basement, and walking down there felt reminiscent of every horror movie I'd ever seen - but if I can go down there and make it out alive, then so can you!
author: Roxane W.

description: Walked all the way from our hotel just to check this place out. Friendly locals, cheap and strong drinks along with a super cool owner. Will definitely be coming back here
author: Jose R.

description: BEWARE. I just got off work nearby and thought it would be fun to go to Chinatown with a coworker last night. I think the Saturday bartender banks on tourists and drunks to not be paying attention. My order came to 24$, I gave him 30$...he gave me nothing back. When I asked for my change he grabbed 5 (NOT 6) OUT OF HIS TIP BUCKET, then I had to ask for my extra dollar. watch your change on Saturdays folks. I still tipped, but he got half of what I was going to give him.
author: Sarah S.

description: I had a Buddha beer at Buddha Lounge. The dragon mural looks happy. That is all. And, I should've taken the bartender's advice and gotten dim sum takeout somewhere on Stockton instead of the crappy place we ended up going to.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Was in Chinatown last night for dinner when Tracy found this place on Yelp... we ended up hanging out all night, making friends with Mark the awesome bartender, and playing dice with other regulars.

The place isn't fancy, but the drinks are good, the jukebox has a WIDE variety, and the people are friendly.

All in all, I'd say the place was *en fuego* ;-)
author: Dee A.

description: We were walking around Chinatown and decided that we needed a beer. Yea, it was 2pm but we were about ready. We stopped in at Buddha Bar and grabbed a seat and hung out with the other patrons. Tourists, regulars and even bar staff hanging out before their shift. Bartender was super nice. Offered us some strawberries. Liars dice and sports on TV. Great mid afternoon stop off.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: My girlfriend and I were out exploring china town later in the evening and happened to stumble into this dive bar. We ordered a couple vodka tonics, and had to stand near the door because it was fairly packed. The drinks were ok, nothing special. The humidity in the bar was intolerable and I had to keep stepping outside to cool down. I wanted to stay longer but I couldn't stand the heat.
author: Lauren T.

description:
This place is always packed and there's limited seating. They do have strong drinks if you're patient enough to get them though. If you're in need of a cocktail and you're in Chinatown then this is the spot.

The beer and wine list is lacking so stick to mixed drinks and you'll be good.
author: Pete F.

description: One word: muay Thais. "But no Christophe, that's two words!" Then clearly you haven't had enough of this 9 dollar signature. Go in for a drink, but don't leave til you've had three.
author: Christophe C.

description: Service and staff were great,  the drink selection  was pretty good,  and the prices were awesome.  It was a little small,  but it was cozy and had great vibes overall.
author: Jake B.

description:
This place is ok. I come here for the first time after a nice dim sum brunch down the street. 

There is only one TV in this hole which is playing the Raider game. This must have been the best game ever played by that team. 

Dark, dingy, dank, dusty, just over all divey. Not that I'm T.C. for a dive, but this was just not my cup of tea. 

The first thing I have is a Chinese brandy poured out of an urn. It is sweet and medicine like. I'm told is an aphrodisiac but sadly the only thing "turned on" was the music which was WAY too loud at times. I had to scream to talk to my friends. The "bartender" is fairly friendly, but any "bartender" who needs coaching to make a proper Manhattan should be water tortured immediately. 

Bathroom is mysteriously gated like it housed Hannibal Lecter in the basement. 

The place kicked us out at 5:00pm on a Sunday. Say whaaaat?!?!?
author: Angelo F.

description: You know those nights... where you're hanging out with a group of friends, and suddenly find yourself whittled down to a few drink-slingers all alone at a weird-ass bar televising Law & Order, that seems to be the only thing open on a deserted street. This was one of those nights. I had to pee. Cross-your-legs and bounce-your-foot pee. But I refused to go here because of the locked iron gate dividing the bar from a staircase that descended underground to the bathroom. Scary restroom situation; scary potent mai tais. I'm going with 4 stars.
author: Christina G.

description:
I'm afraid that if I keep writing these 2 stars reviews about CTown businesses that the mafia is going to come after me...

Well here goes...

Hubs and I were doing our normal weekend routine, drinking all morning at home. We decided to head over to North Beach but we wanted to make a pit stop in Ctown, make sure we didn't lose our buzz. After a bit of Yelping we happened upon Mitsi M.'s hilarious review containing the mysterious cobra drank. So off we went...

From the outside looking in, we thought, "oh hells no" but we were curious about the cobra liquor and the fun times to be had after consuming it.

We saw no cobra drink. Worst yet, it's dark and there is no beer on tap! None. Weird. After one drink we left. Not for us.
author: Kiristen R.

description: I have a knack for finding the most random in the middle of the most unexpected; case in point this lovely spot. Cash only, super cheap, plays crappy early 2000s pop, and the mamasan bartender will challenge you to a Chinese version of Yahtzee. I've already forgotten why I was in Chinatown, but it looks like I'll be here until I remember. Or fall off this barstool. Whichever comes first.
author: Johnny U.

description:
This place smells like black mold and you can actually see it in the men's bathroom downstairs in the basement (yes, this is second hand knowledge).  The woman's bathroom was actually quite clean, but to get there you have to  be buzzed in through a wire gate to get downstairs and you weave yourself through a maze of garbage cans and empties.  

We stayed for a drink and it was the consensus that Li Po across the street is a much better dive bar to visit.
author: Katharine A.

description:
A small quaint little dive bar in Chinatown, I came here to meet up with friends for birthday celebration drinks.  It's a small, rather cozy little place with a lot of regulars that know the bartenders.  Lots of conversation going on, very friendly staff.  Despite it being my first time there, the bartender remembered what I was drinking each time I went up to the bar and happily put together a vodka/cranberry for me each time.  

The prices are *really* good, probably some of the cheapest I've seen in the city.  I could easily drop $20 here and walk away quite tipsy.

A jukebox in the corner provides music so it can range from country to rap to old school heavy metal.  I heard some Willie Nelson followed by old GNR.  The music can get *really* loud in here and given the small size of the place, it's not really good for conversation if someone's fed the music machine.  

Check the place out if you're looking for something new and interesting!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
A dive bar in Chinatown?

A dive bar in Chinatown!!

I'm pretty sure Buddha's is the first bar I've ever been to without beer on tap. If you're looking for some barley and hops it's gonna come in a bottle, and the selection's quite limited. But it never seemed crowded so there's always a stool. Just don't come by on a Sunday, because they're not open.
author: Hugh R.

description:
Liar's Dice...
   Hong Kong Special...
      Missing Memories...
author: Sushi S.

description: This is a must stop on the list of dive bars. The drinks are good and cheap, the bartenders are awesome (always try to go on a night that Mark is working), they usually have cool snacks like popcorn and fried night fish. Just going to the bathroom is an experience, you have to get buzzed down into a basement and if you're tipsy you may or may not go down the last few stairs on your ass..
author: Roxanne R.

description:
Oh my lord.  That night.  The night we went to Buddha Bar.  It will forever go down in history as one of the greatest nights ever.  There were only four of us at the bar, the hilarious bartender and his (what must surely be) stand-up routine and the occasional (very loud and random) Chinese pop song punctuating the conversation.  

I absolutely live for random, weird moments.  You can have your fancy, trendy bars and your $14 martinis.  I'll take a too-strong drink at a dive bar in Chinatown any day.  It makes for a fantastic Wednesday night.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Stopped in for a late night cap, good crowd in this small hole in the wall in, what was by then, a very desserted Chinatown.

Rum and coke for $5, good measure. Bartender was lightening quick. Juke box was very eclectic. Pleasant find.
author: Ross H.

description:
Small place (maybe 12' X 30'), arc-shaped bar with 16-18 black stools (no backs), opposite the bar is a ledge with 6-8 stools (chinese painting on wall above the ledge).

Very tourist-y.  you're drinking with other non-san franciscians (unless you do a shot with the bartender).  "americans" playing dice loudly & obnoxiously (bartender had to officiated/explain the rules the entire time they were playing).  worse part was the way they slammed the damn shaker down....BAM!!  every frickin time.  

No food served.  Bar back includes mirrors, simple shelf, icecicle lights, and supports for a cheesy overhang.  One TV stuck way up in the corner.  A gated downstairs bathroom, so give the bartender a heads up and don't wait until the last minute.  A big downstairs that apparently distributes/monitors electricity to the rest of chinatown.
author: D h.

description:
Haha me and a mate spent a few boozy evenings in here in the late 90s, Ray Price on the juke box.The toilets were below par but
a friendly enough gaff. We stayed just near by at the Grant Plaza. A great place San Francisco, a real swinging town.
author: Chris G.

description: Nice and Sleazy. I love getting buzzed into the bathroom while a patron plays the entire WAR album on the jukebox. Cash only, beer and wine.
author: Chris S.

description:
There are few guarantees in life, setting aside death & taxes. As Lex Luthor's father once told him, "son, stocks will rise and fall, utilities and transportation systems may even collapse, and people are no damn good - but they'll always need land, and for that they'll pay, through the nose.

"Remember that:  land."

Another guarantee?  A bar is only as good as it has to be.

I mean, most bars are--if there's one thing you can count on in a recession (read: "depression"), it's people drinking.  Actually, it's also the one thing you can count on in an economic boom (read: "bubble").  The result is a guaranteed customer pool, so why cater to *those* fuckers?  It's a key tenet of capitalism:  charge as much as you can, and provide as little as possible.

Not the Buddha Lounge!

Located in a very dense urban area, surrounded by hotels and tourist attractions, *any* bar is going to do a brisk business without having to worry about being friendly or having good deals--tourists are one-time customers.  No point in treating them well--fuck 'em.

Not the Buddha Lounge!

I wish I'd gotten the bartender's name, he was simply a great fellow.

Jessica L and I, after a bit of aimless wandering through Chinatown, noticed a neon-lit cocktail glass in the distance, the universal symbol of "drinks be gotten here," and we discovered Buddha's strangely ornate, jade exterior bathed in that red, neon glow (green and red! them's Chinese lucky colors!).

Okay, it's got a divey inside, that's for sure.  A shelf (for people standing) on the left, bar + stools on the right.  Brass rails for your feet, but no coat hooks under the bar (sad panda).  Black security gate in the back, presumably leading to the restroom (more on that in a bit).  I like dives, so no problems there.  It was full of touristy types, the sort of fresh-faced, young adults from parts East or South that stream through SF periodically.  They were celebrating something (either that or shots of whiskey are just something they do on Saturday nights--I can get with that, but you know...).

Jessica L's a bit of a troublemaker.  It was her idea to get the smoke bombs and Chinese poppers, and she hadn't had a sip of her drink before she was winging the poppers out the door, and by the end of the night, she was aiming at other bar patrons' boots.

Best thing about this place?  The bartender.  He caught us tossing poppers, grabbed some, and threw a few himself.  Then he made us drink some kind of Chinese swill that's 88 proof, and taste like cinnamon gasoline.  He did warn us:  "some people think it tastes like cinnamon, some people think it tastes like gasoline."
