You gotta love a bartender who promotes cultural exchange, at the risk of immolating his patrons.

Stumbled out with nothing in our pockets, but had walked in with about $30 between us, so whatever he was charging us, it was a good price.

Recommended.
author: Martin W.

description:
This little bar is cute and fun but nothing too special. I came here one night with a few girl friends because it was right by my old apartment. We had a couple drinks each before going out elsewhere. We also played Liar's Dice (one of my favorite bar games!) with some boys at the bar and the bartender. Because we won, the boys bought us a round of drinks! 

With my victory and liquid confidence, I slipped one of the boys my number as we left the bar. He took me on a nice date a week or two later but nothing came of it...
author: Meghan P.

description:
I'm tempted to say you should just default to Martin W.'s review of this place.  He summed up our night much more eloquently than I can.  So, instead of a long review, I'll post the highlights:
1.  Dive bar with gated bathroom where you have to be buzzed in, for some reason I really liked this
2.  STRONG drinks
3.  Friendly bartender who tolerated, and even encouraged, my raucous behavior
4.  Interesting apple pie/gasoline/cinnamon drink that burned my throat and made me feel like I could breathe fire
5. Good jukebox

I hope to stumble back in here soon.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Haha~! This place was cool. Our bartender was like 70 years old (refer to pic). 

It was a random bar we went into after our nasty drinks at TenRen's. We ordered Irish Car Bombs and our elderly bartender didn't know what that was so...being the cryageeee and clever SF yelpers...they ordered Guinness and Bailey's and made it themselves. We took our shots and left...good times...good times...could've been better...it was a tease. We needed to drink more but we had places to be...
author: Caroline Y.

description: Very nice bar tender! The lady was very cool and offered us free food ;)
author: David V.

description: The doorway is pretty awesome, you can't miss it. It's a dive-bar with not very many seats. We walked in and asked Mark to make whatever he wanted, and he slapped down a drink that was mostly vodka with a bit of orange juice. Cheap, strong, delicious drinks, but I wish there'd been a bit more people (though to be fair it was a Wednesday night).
author: Vicky H.

description:
I never leave thirsty or completely aware of my surroundings.
Great crowd, great staff.
Two thumbs enthusiastically way up..
author: Leif N.

description: Free popcorn awesome bartender came at the beginning of Chinese newyear and got a  free calendar :)!  I will definitely visit again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Emily M.

description:
We walked from the TL all the way up here... I don't quite remember why we did it but I remember there was some sort of reason. But isn't there always a good reason to do something ridiculous when you're wasted?

So we get to china town, probably around 1ish, the place is dead and full of armenians. What the hell? It's a charming small dive. I probably would of like it if everyone there didn't have rapists eyes.

And I don't usually hang out in that area so it was awkward to say the least. I'll be back one day I suppose
author: Debbie P.

description:
I went to the Buddha Lounge about 17 years ago on my birthday. Behind the bar in a large pickling jar there is (was?) liquor with a real (preserved) cobra in it. 

Already drunk, I begged and begged for a shot of cobra liquor. Since it was my birthday and I wouldn't shut up, the bartender (er, Hostess?) gave me a shot. I immediately blacked-out and lost 2 days of my life. This may have been the night I was stabbed but I am not sure since the entire weekend was a blur. 

Moral of the story: never drink cobra liquor.
author: Mitsi M.

description: Cool bar with friendly bartenders.  Don't expect much here, bare bones bar, but just what you need after a day in the city.  Mostly tourists in here with a few locals.
author: Steven H.

description: I've always been too scared to come in here, since it's a small place full of people who are joking loudly with the bartender and I've always felt like I would be the obvious outsider with a poor grasp of Chinese. BUT, I came here late last week and it was pretty fun. The bartender Mark was super nice and mixed fun drinks for us - and even kept refilling my lightweight friend's cup with more water. Drinks were also pretty cheap for San Francisco. CASH ONLY. It was kind of creepy how the bathroom is behind a locked gate and down a flight of stairs, but the bathroom itself was clean. One of the best parts of my night here though, was when he agreed that I did not have to take a shot of 151 with my rowdy guy friends since I was the one paying. Plus points!
author: Melody L.

description:
A great dive bar tucked away in Chinatown. Nothing fancy, no beers on tap, just a few stools, some bottled beer, and a great ambience.

On piece of advice, if the bartender challenges you to a game of Liar's Die for drinks, only accept if you are prepared to lose.
author: Nathan L.

description: A down to earth, non-glamorous, efficient bar that serves goodies. I love their Buddha beer and I try my best to visit this place everything I find myself in the city, cos as a buddhist who never takes religion seriously, i seriously collect the buddha bottles :)
author: Chi-Chi S.

description:
met a friend here after the phish show on friday nite/saturday morning.  Good atmosphere for a dive bar, and they take cash only, so that would keep the tourists out.  $4.50 sierra nevada pales is a nice change too.  the shot glass was dirty, hence why they don't get a 5 star rating.

oh and I rolled by here at 830 on a saturday.  it was dead, empty dead.
author: Pablo E.

description:
I don't usually hang out in Chinatown at night, but if I happen to find myself in the area [once in awhile, I am in North Beach, and that's just a hop, skip, and a jump away], I'll likely stop in at Buddha Lounge. It's small, and there's an old juke box. It's not too loud, so you can easily grab a drink and chat amongst friends for a bit. The bartender [Mark] is great. He pours strong drinks and never fails to crack me up. 

Check the other reviews. You'll see what I mean.

My last visit left me worried for my life, wondering if I was allergic to that random new liquor from China that I decided to be adventurous about and try. Turns out it was just a reaction to an insect bite...

I hear the bathroom's disgusting, so I try to hold it until I get home. But if you really need to go, Mark'll buzz you in. He's got a bathroom gate buzzer every few feet under the bar.
author: Tinna H.

description: Awesome no-frills bar in Chinatown with cheap drinks and plenty of dice to go around.  This is a great spot to chill out and play games with friends (or with the bartender).  I'm a fan!!
author: stacy b.

description: Cool little dive bar in the middle of Chinatown.Went there midday for a cool down and left 3 hours later.Bartender made some good strong drinks and the microwave popcorn hit the spot.
author: Joe P.

description:
My out of town friends and I stumbled upon this hidden bar last night trying to find somewhere to go on a Thursday.  It was within walking distance from Nob Hill, and probably the only dive bar in Chinatown.  

It's very small but has a cozy, down to earth feel to it.  There was no music when we came in and the juke box was only working partially- but I was surprised to see they have a couple of Chinese singer Teresa Deng's CD's, but no Bob Marley!  No matter, we created our own fun with funky dance moves and lots of liveliness. 

I might come back on a weekend just to see how the vibe differs then.
author: Jackie G.

description:
It is very strange in here.......

The downstairs cellar (where the restrooms are located) has a gate on it. Is this where they lock you up if you are misbehaving? If so, then you would have it better than the people upstairs because there is more room in this near empty room than the upstairs bar provides. I would not put it past the bartender to lock you up if you are acting badly, because the bartender seems like the sort of guy who would do this if you got on his bad side. He would also be the type of guy to make sure he fed you plenty of alcohol for your entire imprisonment.
author: Drue C.

description:
I think this is where my friends dad got hit with a bottle on top of his head years ago. 

He wasn't rude. He wasn't drunk. He wasn't cheap. He was white. HAHA, I really don't remember but you got to ask Jimmy for that one. 

Anyway, I haven't came here since last time my friends from Fresno wanted to come here, I had no clue until he told me the story. So when I came in, I will always remember. I came in. I had one quick drink. I had to leave, I knew I didn't belong. Too witty for this area. Oh well....
author: Stanley K.

description:
HOW BUSY IS IT? 
This bar ranges from a quiet night of conversation with Mark (the solitary bartender) to a full on marching band riot spilling out into the street.  (The private birthday party Extra-Action Marching Band performance would not fit inside.)  Most weeknights fall on the quiet side of the spectrum, with unpredictable exceptions.  Fridays and Saturdays can be a little raucous, so if you expect to sit or play dice, come early.  

WHO GOES THERE?
The combination of a Chinatown dive bar with proximity to the financial core and north beach makes for an eclectic mix of patrons.  You can expect to see professionals, hipsters, tourists, gamers, lawyers, misanthropes, locals, gamblers, and drunks.  Misfits welcome.  Occasionally some stripy shirts stumble down from North Beach, but it is more rare than it is common.  

WHAT ABOUT THE BARTENDER? 
If you've heard about the Buddha Bar, you've probably heard about Mark.  Mark is the only evening bartender the Buddha has and he's been working the bar 6 nights a week for almost ten years.  He will serve drinks, tell stories, gamble, shout, flirt with your date, and act as maestro of the madhouse.  Preferred techniques are taking off his pants, shouting, throwing things, et cetera.  To the uninitiated he may seem dangerous or insane.  While these things may actually be the case, getting to know Mark will reveal a different character.  Treat him as a friend and you will learn why so many people come back to the Buddha.  

Also, to the other reviewers: He isn't from Tibet.  He isn't "coked out" either.

WHAT'S THIS ABOUT DICE?
The house game is generally Liar's Dice, though there are other games to be played: Three's, one-four-twenty-four, or just drop 1 die.
If you feel up to it, Mark will play you for a beer, but only if you seem like you know what you're doing.  (It doesn't do his business any good to leave people feeling hustled.)  Also note that he doesn't owe it to you to play with you, so be polite.  Lastly, Mark will not play you "just for fun".  If you want to learn to play, play with your friends first.  You will need the practice.

WHAT IS THAT STUFF IN THE CLAY POT?
It is called "Ng Ka Py", pronounced "NG GA PAY".  It is a Chinese herbal elixir and it is largely there for the tourists.  Given that there is no accounting for taste, I find it to be a vile combination of cough syrup, jaegermeister, and cinnamon mouthwash.
author: joe b.

description: I would totally come back to this bar! They serve good strong drinks!!!
author: Jessie L.

description:
Very strong drinks served by a cheeky chinese bartender in a dark, sticky, sleazy environment in the heart of Chinatown.  Yeah, me rikey.  

(No affiliation with the Buddha Bar in Paris, that I promise you. I promise you that.)
author: Rick H.

description:
Solid four stars... Buddha Lounge is a small, yet lively little bar in the belly of China Town. After squeezing through the door and straight to the bar, we ordered some beers and found a place near the back wall. 

Since Chinese New Year was in full swing, and the parade outside was just about to start, people seemed happy and ready to drink. (Just when you think its just another day of the week someone goes and turns a random holiday into an excuse to drink. I am along for that ride.)

The bartender was hilarious and we chatted it up with him briefly. We asked him about any late night Dim Sum places in the area that he would suggest trying. He compared getting Dim Sum at night to ordering a Egg McMuffin for dinner from McDonalds, it just isn't going to be fresh. We laughed. 

The thing that really got me in the mood for a night on the town was the music. I think we lucked out and miraculously all great songs had been chosen that evening on the Jukebox. At one point I was thinking maybe this was because there was only good music to choose from, but no!! Nelly was in there smiling out taunting someone to pick from "Nellyville." Luckily it was only The Carpenters, Outkast, and some old classics that made it while we were there.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I walked in here with a friend for a drink before we embarked on a night photography tour of the city. Immediately the bartender commented on my camera & asked me if I planned on having lots of drinks.

I took this as, "I'm going to get you drunk, lock you in the basement bathroom area...steal your awesome camera when your drunk ass leaves it on the bar & then sell it while you stand up against the gate screaming about how it's your livelihood & you will die without it". 

Luckily, I had only one drink.
And then we left.
They pour 'em strong here, though.

Just don't visit this place with any valuables--unless you want to get creeped out & potentially lose them.
author: matt m.

description: Friendly bartender, affordable drinks, good company is all you need. I've heard stories about the bartender being infamous about some sort of dice game. Heard he rarely ever loses too. Good luck.
author: Andrew T.

description: Gets four stars just for the Buddha beer. It's a great dive bar in china town o say yes to Buddha bottle beer.
author: Roxy H.

description: It's an okay little dive-y with an okay juke box and good prices for drinks. I really don't like having to be "buzzed in" to the bathroom gate just to take a whiz tho!
author: Nikki M.

description:
This place was dead... which is exactly what I wanted for a quick 15 minute escape from a wedding reception. 

-1 one star for giving me a lemon when I asked for a lime.
+1 star for the bartender claiming he was 'chirish'
-1 star for not having Guinness on tap after such a claim.
Undecided on learning from him that 'once you go asian, you never go back'. Still thinking that one over.
author: Rhett G.

description:
This is one of my favorite dive bars in the city... the drinks are reasonably priced; the jukebox has a great and eclectic selection of tunes so that just about anyone can find multiple songs worth playing; and, the run-down Tiki motif makes it just quirky enough to differentiate it's self from dozens of other dive bars on Grant Street.

The bar is about a block and a half from my apartment - perfect stumbling distance & ideal for "first dates".  I have, in fact, taken so many "first dates" to the Buddha Lounge that Mark the bartender has a whole rating system for their suitability.

Let's just say if he brings me water you're not doing so well... if he brings me a shot?  You're in like Flynn.

Speaking of Mark the Bartender - he makes the entire experience of going to the Buddha Lounge come together tied with a nice, pretty bow.  He is loud and funny and obnoxious and perfectly willing to do shots with you if you happen to be in the bar by yourself.

I spent my birthday evening in the Buddha this year & I had a two-day hangover which I blame mostly on Mark.

This place does tend to get more than an average amount of the dreaded tourist traffic: however, Mark and the regular denizens of the Buddha Lounge are so disdainful and openly hostile to them that they only tend to stay for one drink before heading onto some of the more "tourist friendly" establishments up the street.

I love the Buddha Lounge so much that I would marry it.  :)
author: Kate R.

description: Go to San Francisco and stop onto the buddah lounge for the Chinese Mai tai. Dare I say the best Mai tai I have ever had.  Good atmosphere, good location.  Highly recommend.
author: Tracy G.

description: I was really disappointed with Buddha Lounge.  I walked in during a late afternoon on a weekend -- almost no patrons, no conversation from the bartender, no music, and higher-than-average prices.  The last one really stung me.  If you're going to be completely dead, at least dock me a buck or two on the beers.
author: Bill H.

description: This dive has got a serious funky vibe and it's just a little place- very small bar with about 12 seats. Hey what's that smell?  Oh 30-year old carpet.  No worries though- it's plenty busy and the beer is cold and the drinks are legit.  Both the lady and the guy bartender were funny and really know how to interact with the patrons in a non-annoying way.  It's been awhile since I've been in such a small place.  It's nice to sit and relax away from the packed downtown/SOMA crowd.  Plus, once you're just drunk enough you're only steps away from hundreds of Chinese food restaurants to pick from.
author: Holly B.

description:
We come here annually to kick off the holidays. It's a great bar to get wasted in, cozy and fun and stocked with booze!
Ok, so for the past 2 years they have not been open on Christmas Eve, damnit!
author: Colleen B.

description: After invading TenRen tea down the street, a huge group of Yelpers owned the Buddha Lounge. In the company of SF and LA Yelpers alike, someone chanted Car Bombs and in we went. This place is smaller than my kitchen and we packed it to the gills. As some started to do their bombs, some of us chatted with two girls from Kansas City, who genuinely seemed ready to party even though it was like 2 pm. They also pointed out to us that the doorway looked like a penis. As we got rowdier and rowdier I could see it in the old bartender ladies face that she was thinking, "What in holy fuck is going on here?" So we had our booze, said our goodbyes to the Kansas City girls and the Buddha then went back to it's normal quiet daytime programming.
author: Kim N.

description:
This place is kind of a dump, but in a good way.  It's in Chinatown, but has almost no atmosphere, no niceties, and the drink menu seemed fairly limited.  Definitely not a great spot for girl's night out, and it would be a terrible place to take out-of-towners, but it's not a bad place to grab a drink with a friend.  

The bartender is pretty funny, too.
author: Sarita T.

description:
I have been coming to this bar for years.  This is where I learned to play Liars Dice from a true Master.  Mark, the bartender, has been working there for years and has been voted the craziest bartender in SF for several years now.  Although the bar itself is small and offers nothing more than drinks, it is a great place to hang your hat for a few hours.  

This bar will go through phases where it is super packed with the north beach cast offs, and then suddenly all will be calm and peace will be restored and you will see the regulars that have been coming here for years just hanging out like the old days....

I highly recommend this bar to people who like dark cavernous dive bars where you can just chill and be mellow and have a great time....
author: Yasmine D.

description:
I love stopping here for a cocktail, because of:

- The scathing yet cheap Manhattans,

- The jukebox with Iggy Pop & Kate Pearson's "Candy," and  

- The bartender Mark's committment to defending my ladyhood when a dude starts looming, yelling "back off! Can't you see she doesn't want to talk to you?!" Riveting.

I love stopping here for a cocktail, despite: 

- The creepy downstairs, where I'm convinced I'm going to see a man tied to a chair a la Reservoir Dogs on the way to the restroom,

- Extreme crowding when a bar crawl comes in, and

- Mark the bartender suggesting I might actually be a man. Not sure why.

Still going back.
author: Jill C.

description:
All I gotta say is LIAR'S DICE!

I love this game...and I realized after we left that this was similiar to the game they played in Pirates of the Carribbean II...although the consequences of losing were a little less severe (round of drinks vs your life...heh)

Apparently Tim V is a regular at this joint and he took a friend and I there last night after First Thursday's....what a guy! :-P

It is a bit seedy looking when you walk in.  Dimly lit, long, narrow space...you'd almost expect this to be a place where closet 60 year old alcoholics go to drink away their sorrows (see 65 Club in The Tenderloin).  Alas, the crowd is more mid 20's - mid 30's, all lined up along the bar to quip with the zany barman, Mark.

We got a rough introduction to Liar's dice whilst ordering the first round of drinks.  Apparently Mark was "quite sober" and it was scary how well he played the game.  Ladies, beware this one...he likes to sweet talk you into giving away your knickers or bras....DON'T DO IT!!

The only con I would have to say about this place is that it's pretty small.  We were lucky to get seats when we arrived, although maybe it never gets that packed.

Definitely an experience...and as another reviewer replied early, DEFINITELY not like the Buddha Bar in Paris...haha.
author: Melanie N.

description: Met a friend here for a few drinks, small bar, not a lounge, lol...it smell like one huge bathroom...very dark and low key...but it was quite a hike...it's definitely a dive bar.
author: Spoon P.

description:
I love this bar because of the juke box and cool bartender who treats his regulars and strangers well. 

I always play Boogie Down Productions first thing when I get there then I play something from Blonde on Blonde and embarrass myself singing along emotively. One of the few bars where the speakers are really loud so you get your money's worth when you put on a song.

Once someone put on Steve Miller and I walked out. Don't need to hear that shit when I'm trying to enjoy myself. Jesus why don't you just go to the bathroom and fill your ears with feces?
author: Todd H.

description:
I love it.  It's true what they say other reviews say about the over-abundance of mikey-strip-shirts who are slumming it for a night away from their normal Marina or North Beach haunts: so don't be that guy.  Just because everyone else is too polite (or laid back) to tell you that you're being an ass, doesn't mean you're not.  

Nonetheless, it is a great place to go to start or end a night.  Mark (the bartender) is awesome; one of the few who actually seem to enjoy hanging out with  (or taking money from, via liars dice) the various random fratboys, hipsters, tourists and normals who happen to show up at his bar.
author: Jason C.

description: Cool place....really nice bartender, cheap drinks, dice and good tunes
author: Kate F.

description:
Heres the thing about me.

I like booze. In fact, I love booze. 

Came here one night after work with a co-worker where we decided to be fancy and order a dirty martini and a manhattan. Knowing full well this was a dive in Chinatown where you generally came here to order mulitple beers and stumble somewhere at 2am.
Regardless, the drinks were $4 each. $4 EACH! 


a bargain at any price really though.
author: Erin F.

description:
A pre dotcom crash buddy led me onto this place,  and since then  i've always been a fan.  No, there is no neon,  no dancing girls,  no DJ..   just a jukebox filled with outdated tunes,  an awesome owner/bartender,  several drunks on the other end of the bar,  the occasional tourist peering in at you with disgust,  and a pretty nasty bathroom downstairs.

Oh did I mention they don't skimp on the alcohol?  This is the best place to get drunk period.  Good times!
author: Ryan Y.

description: Is this a lounge? really?  This place is awesome, what makes it awesome is MARC. hahaha... He is off the chain.  Its pretty divey and we went on a Tuesday night, so not very busy.  But people are friendly and the drinks are pretty heavy handed.  I like this place, a good place to be a local.  If you want guaranteed good drinks, inexpensive prices and have some good company with you, this can be the best night of your life, haha. :).
author: Ronjini M.

description: I almost cried because this bar was so bad. Playing dice was the highlight. We got to the bar around midnight on a Friday night and it was empty. A bunch of old dudes sitting at the bar drinking cheap beer. Not a place I would regularly hang out I guess.
author: Debbie C.

description:
In order to get down to the bathroom you must get buzzed in by the bartender and head down through the wire gate.  A bleach bottle held open the bathroom door however it would have been better served in scrubbing the floors.  Scary, keep valuables close to you while in the bathroom if you venture down alone.  Bar not bad, BUT......I wouldn't go again.  Another review from "Eye on the Bay", I don't get what they see in places sometimes or maybe the bar was putting their best foot forward.  

Like the rating says Eek!  Methinks not
author: Dianne M.

description:
It's so awesome here!!!!!

Until it's not.

Until you're asked to feel the sausage.  Repeatedly. Which resides in Mark's pants and he tells you it's special Chinese sausage.  Repeatedly. Ho ho ho hee hee hee funny!!!!! 

Until it's really not.


Foot stampingly stiff  dive bar drinks best imbibed earlier on your way elsewhere than trying to close out the joint.  Weekdays are always preferable.

Things can turn sour when assholes act as such but sometimes Mark will misfire at whoever's closest which is funny... that's right - until it's not.  Liar's dice is a must watch if not try,  there's a back alley "have to go once at least" San Francisco appeal.
author: ChubbyBunny I.

description:
Quickly becoming a neighborhood favorite...

During the week, Buddha Bar is a little "gem" in the heart of an otherwise desolate Chinatown. It really is a "regulars" type of place, so you want to get to know Mark - the only bartender. He's pretty special, see also: perv (I usually leave the bar with my boyfriend prying me loose from his grip), but it's entertaining nonetheless.

I don't mess with dice, but if that's your thing, this is your spot!
author: Valerie N.

description:
Small bar with decent beer selection. Not a bad place to stop by and have a drink on the way home from work. I also like it since it shares the same name as my dog...

Update: Hmm, tried to stop by at 12:32am yet the sign was turned off and the place was closed. They might want to think about adjusting their posted hours as it really pissed me off that I walked out of my way to go there only to find it closed...
author: Nicolas H.

description: The best bar in Chinatown, hell, the best bar in SF. Probably build sometime before the 1906 earthquake. For the ultimate Buddha Bar (correct name) experience,  come here during the Chinese New Year parade. This place will be going fucking crazy, along with the wacko bartender. I actually witnessed the bartender (Mark, Hop Sing, whatever his name) pour 151 down the bar and light it on fire!
author: Brad J.

description: Classic San Francisco dive bar.  Play the bartender (Mark) liars dice to try to win a drink.  Great place to end the night.
author: P T.

description:
THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE BARTENDERS (ALL OF THEM)

buddha bar is actually easily 40 times as awesome than you might think. two thumbs up.

many of you may know mark, but how many of you have actually come here mid-day during turist hours. its actually just as awesome.
author: christopher a.

description: Its a pretty decent Chi-Town place for a cheap drink and easy hanging out with friends from work.  Not fancy and don't sit down on the toilet - best to find another place to do that business, but a good (cash only) place for a cheap drink.
author: Greg R.

description:
This place rocks, cheap drinks, total hole in the wall... great for a stop on a china town bar crawl... Last time i went there it was for one drink w/ a friend, we didn't leave till closing time... fun, friendly, and unique... stop in... its a trip...

oh liars dice with Mark... fun fun fun!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Shatangi takes out of towners on a walking tour of chinatown a few times a year and Buddha is always  the end of the line. Awesome neborhoody bar in the middle of tourist limbo.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
Ahh the Buddha Lounge...right in the heart of Chinatown. A great hip tiny dive bar, that one must venture into while in the area. 

What's a better way, err excuse to celebrate Chinese New Year at the Buddha Lounge downing down some Tsing Tao (there was no way I couldn't pass up an asian beer on Chinese NYs!).

Drinks were set at your average prices. The bartender running the place on his own was very nice, humorous, & fast to serve us. 

Tiny little bar, but it's fun squishing into this bar decorated in a variety of asian decorations. Best of it, a jukebox by the door. With some surprisingly great old school hits (Ranging from Michael Jackson, The Carpenters, to even Nelly). 

The bathroom was an interesting adventure. I nervously walked through this cage door that led downstairs. To my surprise it was more of a storage area, and then up these tiny steps to a door in the corner (right for women, left for men). Then I thought it was a good idea to think of the worst. What if I get stuck down here, or what if a killer is after me, or I get kidnapped & eaten by a monster. So I rushed out the bathroom, scaring myself while swooshing past the cases of beer stored downstairs......heeeey wait a minute, can't anyone take these beers?! 

Overall great adventure! Hopefully i'll be stopping in again someday. :)
author: Catherine O.

description:
Patience, forbearance, compassion, and the search for inner peace.  These are all qualities exemplified by Buddha.  The bartender exemplifies none of these qualities, nor does he try.  This is a man who speaks his mind, whether you like it or not.  That's what makes this place great.

Great f'n jukebox.  Cash, Willie, Orbison, Chemical Bros, Physical Graffitti... you get the point.

I tried the mysterious liquor with the Chinese label.  Rumor has it that this made a previous customer cough until he choked out a toenail the bartender lost when stomping out this drink in the basement.  I didn't fare much better.  Just ask for the "boo-GAH-bee."
author: Rob R.

description: Two words: LIARS DEN!! Great place, good people and atmosphere!
author: Jesus G.

description:
Great place to plan heists in, provided you know one brain, some muscle, a loose cannon and at least one femme fatale. Go over "The Job" with your crew during the day before the bar fills with yeggs.

That said, I find it retarded when a perfectly grand old Dive starts trying to identify itself as a Lounge. This glorious shit-hole may have qualified as a Lounge as late as the Nixon era, but no longer.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Marc (from Tibet) is crazy....how crazy is he? he sat and stared at us as we ordered a beer from down the bar and promptly puked on his shoes..service didnt stop....although we did have our doubts.  But liars dice and cheap beers plus  hilarious banter with Marc. Man, the dude can kick ass at dice and then more banter with his wife at the end of the night. 
good times. 
dont get lost in the dundgeon of a bathroom though.
author: Diego C.

description:
Buddha Rocks!

Buddha is always cool 
Nice statues and art work aroud the place 
Always something is going on
some party or something or other 
Interesting Cocktails
author: AZAM A.

description: One word: Mark.  The bartender is the most interactive I've met.  He plays games with you, remembers your names & drinks.  Most charming, personal bar in SF.  Reminds me of boondock saints!
author: Tyler R.

description:
I would have liked this place a lot more had I visited it with one friend rather than 5. What is up with SF bars having no group seating?
The bartender was great, playing some sort of dice game with the customers and telling jokes. There is some sort of gated portal to the bathroom you have to be buzzed into to use, which was highly intriguing. When we first walked it, the darkly lit place was blasting modern country music, which was jarring and almost made us turn around and leave, till we realized it was a jukebox that we quickly took over (really nice motown selection, by the by). I would suggest this place to duets out and about, or people who wore better walking shoes than we did and don't mind getting drunk on their feet.
author: Tori B.

description: Pretty awesome jukebox.  They don't lather your ass with butter so that keeps a lot of the bougie crowd away. Great spot to have on a bar crawl.
author: Roger H.

description: I had been wanting to go here simply because of the name- I thought it might've had some cool Buddha theme. Well not exactly, but at least I could tell that they were trying to go for that look, with the hanging above the bar. Still it's a cool little dive, and I'm glad I went! The bartender was super friendly and helpful, she rocked!
author: Sonya D.

description: Kind of a quirky little special San Francisco Chinatown dive with preppy patrons who play drinking games with the bartender. Good prices, and cool location make this a decent place for a pitstop.
author: Andrew K.

description: This is a great local find if you just want a place to chill with a few friends while in chinatown. It is pretty small (and cash only), but it has a really good vibe for a dive bar. Most importantly, the bartender rocks! He definitely makes the place.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I've been living here for three years & I'd never been out for a night of barhopping in Chinatown. My buddy Paul Clark suggested we start out at Buddha. I knew he'd been there a few times, but I wasn't prepared for the reaction he got when we walked in. "Where you been"? asked the bartender, as he lined him up a complimentary shot of Makers Mark. It went like this all night. Lots of shit talking, laughing & drinking. At one point, a whole bunch of dudes on rollerblades rolled in (literally rolled), & this was at 11pm. Yes, seriously. The proceeded to put a ton of Elton John & the Eagles on the jukebox, & the bartender upped the volume just enough to achieve Maximum Awesome. I hate the fucking Eagles, but for one night I couldn't get enough. It's the kind of place that can get away with that & earn love in return (when generally, the Eagles will bring only scorn).

Before we went out, I was sceptical. I really didn't wasn't sure I was going to like the whole 'barhopping in Chinatown' thing, but after Buddha, I threw that idea right out the window. A five star dive if there ever was one.
author: Pete J.

description:
Tiny place with a dungeon for a restroom and  talkative barman

If I were a local I'd go from time to time
author: Sergio R.

description:
It was getting late, and we were being a typical indecisive group and didn't know where we wanted to go. "I want Chinese food", "I need to charge my phone first"....ok let's just use yelp and find a dive people! So we did and we came up with Buddha Lounge. 

I went with one friend and the others were supposed to meet us (although they never did) I still had a really good time. Dives are not my fave, but from time to time I am reminded that they can be a fun change of scenery. 

The bartender here rocks! There is only one so you will not get confused. Let him do his thing and mix you up mini cocktails or if you are brave you can try some sort of Korean Whiskey he keeps behind the counter in a funny shaped brown bottle. I was a fan of his "delicious" cocktail which had strawberry and orange vodka, club soda, ice and lime.He will chat, play dice with you, leave the bar for a quick smoke and pretty much make your stay as fun as possible. 

The place was pretty empty (but it was a Tuesday) and a little dirty (but it's a dive). No complaints at this dive. Fun bartender and 4 drinks for $24, not bad. Oh, and the neon pink sign out front is a priceless tacky addition to the bar.
author: Theresa T.

description:
my favorite bar in SF.
mark (the ever present bartender) will make you feel welcome and his tales of woe and misery will make you feel better about yourself.
author: Da Wei S.

description: I dont totally remember, but I think I had an amazing time here!
author: Fudge D.

description:
If you are into divebars, buddha is mecca.

This place is nothing w/o Mark though so make sure he's working when you go and ask him to play a game of dice for your next drink.
author: Dpb T.

description:
Cheap, quick, small. I probably would not spend my whole night here, but it's a great place to stop for some cheap drinks. You'll definitely find some weird people here - I think we were drinking with some homeless woman who came in off the street and bought some drinks - but the bartender is kind of funny and pours your drinks strong. 

tbh, if I were a single female, I definitely would not come here alone...
author: Leo C.

description:
What is this bartender guy's deal?  He's pretty insane, but I like it.

Equal parts grungy and dim this place is fun if you or a friend are down for some verbal sparing with a bartender we has a fair grasp of the english language.
author: Andy G.

description:
When I first moved to San Francisco one of my friends told me "We have to go to Buddha Bar in China Town, the bartender is nuts."  Cool.  I filed it away and then another friend told me he went there last Friday and stayed all night rolling dice for drinks and came out on top.  He hardly had to pay for a drink all night.

Sounds like my kind of place.   And it was.  At first it was very quiet.  Saturday night and only a hand full of folks in the place.  But it didn't matter.  By my second drink I worked up the courage to say, "I wanna roll dice for my beer!"

I've never seen a bartender get so excited.  The previously quiet chines man behind the bar started going nuts.  "Oh, I love to roll dice!  What game?"

Me- "Uh, what game should I play?"  Of course I knew nothing of rolling dice but we settle on 1-4-24.  I kinda knew the rules from my friend's previous visit and went along with it.

I roll first.  One and a four on the first shot.  I keep 'em because I like to play it safe.  Next roll, a couple of fives.  My buddy tells me to keep just one.  I do.  Third roll puts gives me a six to keep.  Final roll, two sixes.  23 son!  Mark the bartender couldn't match it.  Free beer for me!  Beginner's luck?  I think not.  Dice is a game of skill, right?

Mark gave me a lot of shit for beating him but he was just having fun.  I could tell he loved his job, especially when dice was involved.  He kept telling me how the beer tasted better when you win and you know what?  He was right.

Not to mention the jukebox here is one of the best I've seen in the city.  It gives this review it's final fifth star.  Mark, I'll see you next Saturday my friend.
author: Aaron G.

description: Do you remember those inscrutable Asian people that San Francisco tried to quarantine and deport? If those stereotypes were true, they probably would have hung out at this bar. One ugly ass dragon mural and one bottle of TsingTao. Need a I say more? My urban gene pool clearly knows how to rock. Sadly, Mark, the bartender, claims only 2% of that gene pool actually steps foot in the place. No happy hour and four dollar beers though.
author: Wendy L.

description:
This place is small, dark, and the locked door for the stairwell to the bathrooms make this place feel sketchy. Definately a low-rent sorta place.

Ignoring that, its a cool spot for a drink. The seating is interesting... 

I will confirm that the bartender is cheeky :)
author: Tom S.

description:
I gave it 2 stars because it's ok, but yea...I've experienced better. :)  Below is my reasoning.

Buddha is alright by atmosphere and decor alone...  Like Leo C. said, I probably wouldn't be here the whole night.  Music is ok, drinks are alright and the crowd is...well, I don't notice them so much.  Plus, it's not usually completely full.

However, with all that said, I think places are more about the people you are with so if you're with a group of friends, this place isn't all that bad.
author: Hannah S.

description: On a crazy night in the city involving getting lost in Chinatown, we stumble into this bar it seems like it's the only one open at the time. We walk in and it's a dive, fully lit a few older Chinese gentlemen having some fun playing some kind of bar video game. Ok well we will still get a drink before we taxi home. I went to the bathroom and discover an underground dance club TOTALLY PACKED. What??!! Not a nice dance club but the vibe was really funky. It felt almost like you were in your friends basement...with laser lights and a bar....but still with the funky couches from the 70's. This is my all time fav dive bar/lounge, it really is legendary.
author: sophie p.

description: As a part of my short C-town pub crawl: Old Crow was their well whiskey, 'nuff said.
author: Diana C.

description:
I have been coming to Buddha for almost six years now and Mark never fails to put a smile on my face.  I have been with him through his marriage and the birth of his child, which has, unfortunately, slowed down his frenetic style a bit.  

Never the less, this is place I can always go to have a drink, a friendly chat, and usually hustle some free drinks from tourists who want to play liar's dice with us...
author: Jesse C.

description:
as far as dive bars go, this one was pretty good.
visited Chinatown on a day a festival was being held and only escaped into it to get away from the crowds and find a restroom.
instead we found a group of dutch marines and some cheap beers.
spent the next couple of hours chatting with them and watching them air guitar with the stools to some johnny cash.
the bartender was efficient and didn't seem to mind them goofing off.
i suppose it can easily be a hit and miss.. but this day was definitely a hit.
author: Rosemary C.

description: Wonderful dive bar in Chinatown.  Good crowd.  Friendly and totally funny bartender, he has so much character.  Lots of good beer choices.  We were only planning to be here for an hour or so and ended up staying for 4 hours until they closed because it was so much fun.
author: Yun W.

description: This place looks really cool on the outside but really sux.  To take a piss you need to get special permission and buzzed in to the basement, they don't play any music unless you feed the jukebox which sux again because me and the solo dutch tourist were feeling pretty awkward in that shathole.  Then to top it off I am in there at 6pm and ask about happy hour  . There is no happy hour!  She said we don't need happy hour here.  You don't?  I was the only one in the place and I'm local and won't be back.  piss off!
author: Kyle K.

description:
Mark, the bartender is ta great guy. 
Excellent Chinatown spot. Serious boozing...
Sam Woos is across the street....
Classic Chinatown experience.
author: otto p.

description: We've been here a few times in the morning to eat Chinese food at the bar and start drinking early. The older lady who works then is nice and will make a good bloody mary but the REALLY GOOD time to go there is at night when Mark is working. We went to a comedy show at Cobbs one night then hit up the Buddha Bar and Mark was funnier than the comedian we saw. It's a little place, can sometimes be crowded, with a creepy bathroom where you have to go downstairs into what's almost a dungeon/stock room but hearing Mark's jokes, having some good drinks and looking at all of the decor on the walls more than makes up for that.
author: Marty S.

description: Where Mark the bartender will offer you a handjob for a five star yelp review and pour you generously portioned "whiskey and delicious"es without any hesitation. The jukebox is stacked with classics, the drinks are stacked with alcohol, and the bartender is one of the funniest and craziest guys around. This place is a riot, and I'm not just saying that cause the bartender offered me a sexual favor.
author: Keane N.

description: Chinatown dive bars would be much more pleasant if they weren't done to death by overprivileged white kids.
author: Megan W.

description:
ahh the clash of tumblers playing liars dice, wonderfully drunken conversations and one of sf's most entertainingly awesome bartneders Mark. over the past 6 years i've had everything from my ass handed to me by perfect strangers at gambling to Mark not so helpful advice to a date about how to best end the date...ahh the buddha

If you're anywhere near china town or north beach- buddha is the spot to start/or dangerously end- the night. Extra points for being next to sam wos! woot! fiver stars easy
author: Tim V.

description:
I really can't review this bar.  I stepped through the doorway to see what all the fun was about and then continued on my way.

You see, I was walking past on my own mission from God when I hear people singing and laughing and music playing.  That always gets my attention.

What I found was a bar.  To call it a lounge is a stretch of anyone's imagination.  This is a bar like a cantina in Mexico is a bar. 

Anyway I don't know if they were yelpers, but they should have been seeing as how much fun they were having on a Sunday afternoon in the heart of Chinatown.

I'll give it 3 stars since I didn't stay, but you can obviously have a great time there if you choose.  If I were part of the group I found in there I'm sure I would give it 4 stars.

Check it out for yourself.
author: Brian M.

description: Yeeeeeeeeehaaaaw!   Poor dear Kendra sat at the bar and took shots and drank car bombs until she had to be slung over a man's shoulder and carried off the scene.  That was 6:49pm (I exaggerate...A little).  By 8pm Liar's Dice was in full force around 3/4 of the bar.  We had a monopoly on the juke box by 8:02pm.  By 8:07 rounds of shots were being taken by at least ten people simultaneously - strangers at that.  I wish I could give an estimate as to when we wandered up the street, but the psychic bartender had my vodka-soda full before I could put down the glass.  It was a good night indeed.  Everytime I go here, I have a blast.  The restrooms are over the hills and through the woods though, keep that in mind when you're knockin' em back.
author: ellyk E.

description:
discovered this place when my friend, who'd been living in phoenix for the past couple months, calls me out of the blue a little after midnight and says, "jane! i'm in chinatown!" to which i responded incredulously, "there are chinese people in phoenix?!" turns out he meant he was here shooting dice.

it's little, dimly lit and seems to always have the same indescribable smell throughout. this is the spot.
author: Jane P.

description: mark the bartender is da sh't. he is the reason on why I keep going. yes it's super dive-y, yes the gated bathroom is creepy, but mark has nice stories and the crowd is friendly, a perfect place to zone out. if you like fancy people and sparkling mini skirts, go elsewhere.
author: C J.

description: I want to see David Lo Pan from "Big Trouble in Little China" here so bad. I keep going just in case he shows up.
author: Katelin H.

description: My Tequila was watered down, but this was a a convenient place to grab a quick drink while shopping.
author: Sunny D.

description:
go play liar's with mark...i dare you...look into the eyes of the craziest bartender in the city and call him a liar...do it and see what happens...

if you're lucky, i'll be there to play too.  then we'll all be drinking and you'll be paying!  maybe even goofy and steven will stop by and you can buy them a round too.  

great place to go, especially during the week, when the crowd is thinner and you can easily find a stool.  and you can get an education too.  last time, mark informed us on the interesting history of tsingtao beer (its german).
author: eric g.

description:
Try to come here whenever I come back to Northern California. The beer selection is lacking, there's not too around that's open around midnight, but it's just a good place to get drunk. Small dive with a jukebox and an entertaining bartender (Mark). Mark will yell at you, be nice to you, show you the panty drawer, play dice, or offer you some stinky ass liquor. 

True, there are the frat boys and their future trophy wives, but there are also the bikers, the after work folks, once I saw a wedding party stumble in with the bride still in her wedding dress.
author: Lyn G.

description: My friends had really talked this place up, so I was expecting fireworks. What I found was a sparse, tiny bar right in the heart of Chinatown. Free popcorn and a friendly bartender. This place is cash only.
author: Britt R.

description: This is a great local find if you just want a place to chill with a few friends while in Chinatown. It is pretty small (and cash only), but it has a really good vibe for a dive bar. Most importantly, the bartender rocks! He definitely makes the place. Thanks Mark
author: David E.

description: This bar is truly a hole-in-the-wall hidden dive bar - and I love it! The bartender was kind and the drinks are reasonably priced (just bottled beer though).  Buddha is a VERY small bar although there had to have been no more than 10 people inside on a Saturday night.
author: Scott G.

description: Definitely one of the best dive bars in the city.  It has the cheapest drink options, colorful decor, the bar tender is friendly and funny and always chatting it up, and it seriously has the best jukebox selection in the city, hands down.
author: Shayna N.

description: Classic and comforting culture clash. Hong Kong honkey tonk. Super low key place to have a beer with friends. I feel like the people who become regulars here must have been all around the world and decided that no single culture has got it all right - so might as well try to smash them all together in a single San Francisco style dive.
author: Alex B.

description: The first time I went to this bar was during a bar crawl through Chinatown. Mark is probably one of the most unique bartenders in the city. I recommend a couple games of liars dice but recommend to stay away from doing shots of the strange bottle of Chinese liquor behind the bar. D-A-N-G-E-R-O-U-S!
author: Amy C.

description: What a fun place, my partner and I always stop in here after our frequent food frenzy up the street at the R&G Lounge. We always have a great time with the local patrons, and tourists. The bartenders certainly know how to pour a drink, and as dive bars go, I love the atmosphere (My partner thinks it is a little beneath him, but he is from the Orange Curtain, what does he know? Love him still) but, I have a great time, and that's what matters. Just one word of warning, if you have to pee, whatever you do, go use the Ladies Room trust me...
author: Anthony K.

description: The greatest dive bar in San Francisco and probably the best i will ever go to.  There is only one word that defines this place : MARK.  The greatest dive bar also has the best most perverted bartender in the world. This guy is absolutely hilarious.  I mean what bartender tells you taht he doesnt need viagra but instead he uses a technique where he inserts a pin needle in his peehole to stay fully erect for the whole day.  Those are the priceless moments that you come away with at this bar.  Come here for your birthday becasue Mark will pour you the biggest fuckin shot in the world.  And the best part is that its on the house.
author: Anton E.

description: This is the best dive bar! I have been here on several occasions and it is pretty much what you see is what you get. It's small, dark, with no frills....except for the amazing bartender (who will even do shots with you)! You can play liar's dice for drinks, and last time we were there my husband mentioned that he liked one of the pint glasses, and they bartender gave him one, for free! There's nothing fancy or amazing about it, you bring the fun and create the atmosphere, that's what makes it fantastic....might even head there tonight on our way out of town! P.s. the buzzing to go to the bathroom, then walking down the stairs into the basement was a little scary/weird at first, but hey, it's the city, it's an adventure, and that's why we love this place!
author: Erika F.

description: Yes, Mark the bartender is surly. Yes, he will curse at you and your friends throughout the evening. Yes, the basement looks like a place where they'd have cock fighting. But where else in SF can you play liar's dice for drinks?
author: Dave S.

description: Let me tell you a story about this fabulous place. Last time I was there, the bartender decided that 2AM should not be the closing time for the bar, which made my group very happy. Then he turned to the juke box, chose a song, and proceeded to fully square dance with me (complete with do-si-do's and twirls).  Then he kissed me, in front of his wife, who was laughing hysterically (note- the kiss was a very chaste "muah"). The lyrics of the song were something to the effect of "We're going to Texas, but we're not getting married." It was definitely a memorable night.
author: Noelle Q.

description: Best bartender in San Francisco ... hell I might even go out on a limb and say best bartender in the United States of America. I love this place.
author: Bart C.

description: What an awesome hole in the wall dive bar!  The place is super low key and with a completely a chill vibe.  It's never super busy and the bartender Mark is one funny dude.  The drinks are affordable with healthy pours, but there's only bottled beer.  Having actually used the restrooms, the men's room at least wasn't nearly as bad as I had expected.  There's also a jukebox with some classics.  It's a great place to meet up with friends and shoot the shiz over a couple of cold ones.  I will definitely be back.
author: Gary L.

description: I'm giving them five stars simply for the fact that they have a weird steel gate leading down to the bathrooms and you have to be 'buzzed in' to use them.  Once down there I can't help but think of the film 'big trouble in little china' and all of the crazy fun antics that entails.  Seriously I think their basement is hooked up to some sort of subterranean cave system that runs underneath the san francisco chinatown connecting various homes, bars, and restaurants.  I'm dead serious too check that shit out next time you enjoy a frosty and reasonably priced tsingtao with one of the friendly bartenders.  I can't wait to be hella drunk so that I can invite a few of my dearest friends to go on a spelunking party down in this bitch.  Macho Man Randy SAvage says OHHHHHHHHHHHH YEAHHHHHHHHHHH!
author: Francis K.

description: Any bar where you can play liar's dice with the bartender to win your drinks is alright with me.  When that bartender is Mark.... ten times better.  The crowd here is almost always chill.   I do everything I can to avoid using the basement bathroom where I may or may not get shanghaied and never be seen again.  Later in the evening you can even find close parking, although driving there never seems like a good plan.
author: Dina A.

description:
i have only been here once, but it made quite an impression. 

i was in chinatown due a toy camera seminar that i was taking. after walking around chinatown for 3 hours taking pictures of anything and everything, i met up with a friend and we decided rather than walk around some more, that we would pop into this litte bar on the corner of grant and...something. it is little. very little. but that is part of the charm. it's just got one long bar, and a jukebox. The beer was cheap, the jukebox stocked, and the owner, very entertaining. he kept dancing to every song played from r&b and hip hop, to rock, to country, to synth pop. if i lived in the area, that place would be my neighborhood bar. period.  a fantastic little dive.
author: Caddy M.

description: This place is complete shit! I HEART IT HARD! The few times I have come it has been with a big group of friends that pretty much use this place as their second home. The drinks are strong. The games are weird, the bathrooms are something out of a snuff film, and the bar tender is creepy. He likes to play his parody songs from his ipod and flirt with every customer in there, man, woman, tranny, hobo, anything with genitalia really. It's great fun.
author: danny e.

description:
A fun little dive bar in the heart of Chinatown, the Buddha Lounge is a great place to get a drink when you need to ditch your touristy family while they spend decades inside a jewelrey store. 
I tried to explain to my sister-in-law that you will find many of the same items in all the stores on Chinatown--there isn't a whole lot of variation. Alas, she insisted on examing every item in the store and after an hour and a half, I decided to escacpe to the Buddha Lounge for a beer with my cousin.

Thank god for that. We had a laugh with the very hilarious, now infamous bartender Mark and played some music on the jukebox. The drinks were cheap and the place was fun, but mostly I was just happy to get away from my family for a while.
author: Nicole R.

description: I Loved It! We went in a limo as a traditional birthday stop before dinner, and it was just like I remembered. The bartender, Mark was awesome and I know I will be there in 365 days again.
author: monika l.

description: What a crazy place?! My evening ended here after a night of bar hopping. My friends and I jumped right into an intense game of Liars Dice (my favorite) with the bartender Mark. Following the house rules, my friend who lost ended up buying us all a round of Ng Ka Py. (I read the other reviews after the fact to actually figure out what the horrid stuff was. NASTY!) Afterwards, Mark proceeded to walk around the bar, chat up some other patrons, and caught me by surprise by dipping me off the bar stool and planting a smooch right on my lips. I thought he was gay!!! What a crazy dude. What a crazy night.
author: Lauren Y.

description: I beat the bartender twice at dice and got free beers (much to the bartender's pouting and complaining about how my dice were rigged), I've drank with two old ladies wearing about a tube of lipstick each, and have been knocked off my bar stool by the strength of 4 Manhattans. How can you not love a bar like that?
author: Rebecca H.

description: Anyplace you can play the bartender a dice game for drinks is okay in my book.
author: Ossama A.

description:
This place DOESN'T accept foreign tourists on Saturday nights or at least not from certain countries. Probably they want to keep a local unstylish atmosphere.
Last Saturday I went there with my wife. The bouncer didn't accept her passport as a valid ID, trying to quote some (unexisting) new rules from the bureau of alcoholic beverage control, ...
I asked him how, e.g. a British tourist could go into the pub, and he answered that he should get an ID from the DMV!! (everybody knows DMV does not issue ID's for non residents like tourists). 
If this illiterate employee of Mandala Lounge ever saves enough for a trip to Europe, it would be nice that he is forced to stay out of all nightclubs and is refused any alcoholic beverage.
author: Mario S.

description: The bartender is great.  Always funny and friendly. You'd think he'd get tired of dealing with drunken fools and become jaded or unfriendly like must SF bartenders. Right across from Li Po so you can get your Chinatown dive bar experience.  Buddha would be rolling over in his stupa if he were a judgmental kind of guy since I'm not sure the Middle Path leads to this bar, but it's a nice stop along the way.
author: Surf R.

description: Mark is hilarious-he's always molesting my friends hands and always down for a game of liar's dice. Last time, I got to see Mark's bra collection! Scary to say the least! Fun experience, great local bar and usually their are some interesting people.  It's only a 3 because of the bathroom!
author: Olivia W.

description: Definitely a dive with character! The bartenders are quirky and fun, lots of interesting people to meet there, and something always weird happens when I go (i.e. boobie exposure).
author: Joy C.

description:
This is one of the best dive bars in the city. Mark the bartender is the funniest & drunkest bartender there is. The drinks are really stiff & the juke box is great.
The place is not much fun without Mark, but when he is around you are in for an experience to remember. The other nice thing is you get good crepes next door, for those late night cravings. Its in China town & all the good restaurants are walking distance..so just GO!
author: Randy M.

description: Good tunes, good barman, great neighborhood, long live the Buddha!
author: Phil W.

description: Great small dive bar right in the bustle and hustle of Chinatown.  Cheap drinks, nice folks... very chill place to stop by every once in a while.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Perfect place for bringing your out-of-town pals. Then take them to Tosca. And maybe the Tonga Room.
author: Juliette T.

description: I tried this place for the first time about a month ago and have already been back 3 times.  The prices are cheap, the drinks are strong, and the bartender is fun.  Jukebox is decent and the bar never gets too crowded.  This will definitely be a neighborhood bar I will frequent.  I also tried the Maotai after reading one of the reviews below.  It's smooth, but not really my thing!  But, I'll probably get it again on a night when I've had  many a drink.
author: Shawna S.

description: Tiny little hole in the wall that's great for low-key, Chinatown hangin' out. Get a bottle of somethin' cheap (forget about taps or a decent well drink) and kick back.
author: Andrew L.

description: It's small.  It's in Chinatown.  The Juke box is PACKED with amazing music that it hard to find at even Treat Street.  Go here if you want to impress your friends with your musical knowledge, or if you want to get drunk before heading over to LiPo.
author: Ben H.

description:
Once when I was there, this woman who pretended to be named Kristina and pretended to be from Norway, and talked with a fake accent, but really was from North Dakota, she got up on the bar and started pouring Ketel One all over herself, and all over the bar, one bottle after another, so that there was like, an inch-and-a-half of expensive crappy vodka all over the bar.  And then she started rubbing herself all over the bartender to dry herself off, but really she was just getting him really wet.  And then he lifted up his shirt to start to ring it out, and then she started to lick his nipples.  

Meanwhile, this father and son tourist combo from Ireland, named -- I kid you not -- Patty and Patty O'Flannery, sit there no more than two feet away, Ketel One dripping off the bar and off the now soaked and see through shirt of the pretend Norwegian - ja! - totally absorbed in a game of yahtzee cup liar's dice.  And these two Irish lads -- they even called themselves a coupla lads from the old country -- are completely, utterly drunk.  And when the Chinese bartender finally saunters over and tells them he's Irish too, from County Cork, they all have a laugh, and Patty and Patty pay for the 4 bottles of Ketel One spilled all over the place.  And then a Russian cab driver named Dmitry pulls up outside, and the Chinese Irish bartender throws Patty and Patty in the back of the cab, and he pulls off, and then within no more than 90 seconds, the Clash song on the jukebox screeches to a stop, everyone's kicked out, and the bar is closed for the night. At 11:23pm.  

For relaxing times!
author: John Z.

description: Went here back in November with my crew after having dinner at nearby Great Pearl or some name like that. We met my bro's friend who worked nearby. Simple little bar, but I thought it was weird yet cool that you had to go through a gate to go down to the basement for the bathroom. They serve your standard beers, liquor & mixed drinks, all reasonably priced. Service was good this night. If I ever eat in Chinatown again, I'll most likely stop by here for post-meal drinks.
author: A N.

description: This is the only bar I've been to in Chinatown that is just the kind I like (dark-ish, divey, room to sit, etc.) Pricier drinks than mission bars, I think because there is no happy hour, but great otherwise
author: Emma H.

description: this is actually a really cool little spot in chinatown. i used to walk by it every night on the way over to a friends house and finally i decided to stop in and see what it was like. fun people and a hilarious bartender who likes to yell.
author: Michelle I.

description: a pitcher of tsingtao and the jukebox is suddenly alive
author: Ty X.

description: the bartender from canton, china bought me a shot.  nuff said.
author: Pickle R.

description: We went to the Buddha Lounge last night with a group of about a dozen people.  I used to go there about 10 years ago and it was always a nice mellow bar.  The bar isn't too crowded but lively.  As everyone mentions, Mark the bartender is a landmark.  He has worked there for nearly 14 years and is still about as friendly as they come.
author: Don T.

description: funky little bar in chinatown.  i like the outside of this place - lots of style.  i can't really speak to the crowd, because i stopped in on a week night and it wasn't very busy.  the bartender was nice, and made good suggestions of what beers to get, and offered some type of scandalous-smelling shots that i was absolutely afraid to try.
author: Carolyn B.

description: I don't really know how to explain my experience here.  I left drunk/happy and felt a little dirty/violated all at the same time.  Everything that everyone else has said is true, good or bad.  I think it is all in how you tolerate a little bit of insanity and a hefty amount of drinking.
author: mike V.

description: great divey, local bar in chinatown. the bartender is great. you'll be on a first name basis by the end of the evening. the jukebox kicks ass and the drinks are relatively cheap. and it's great to grab a drink and watch the tourists roam through chinatown like mindless cattle, but with pockets full of money and cheap souvenir fetishes.
author: Dean E.

description: Small place with tons of character. The patrons are good to drink with but the bartender makes the place. Play liars dice for rounds and he may just join in. Jukebox too.
author: Dave S.

description: This is definitely one my favorite bars in SF. Great location, one of the most colorful bartenders that I've ever come across (Mark), and liar's dice! Small, hole-in-the-wall, spectacular dive bar.
author: jason m.

description: definitely not a clubby bar if that's what you're lookin for. just a nice place to stop in have a couple drinks. small corner bar-plenty of locals bogarting the jukebox, only drawback is that it's cash only but other than that-fine by me.
author: ali m.
